(This is a conflict only for proposals or applications that originate from the department, school, or facility that the visiting committee or similar body advises.) • Any office, governing board membership, or relevant committee chairpersonship in the institution. (Ordinary membership in a professional society or association is not considered an office.) • Current enrollment as a student. (Only a conflict for proposals or applications that originate from the department or school in which one is a student.) • Received and retained an honorarium or award from the institution within the last 12 months.

2. YOUR RELATIONSHIP WITH AN INVESTIGATOR. • Known family relationship as spouse, child, sibling, or parent. • Business or professional partnership. • Past or present association as thesis advisor or thesis student. • Collaboration on a project or on a book, article, report, or paper within the last 48 months. • Co-editing of a journal, compendium, or conference proceedings within the last 24 months.

3. YOUR OTHER AFFILIATIONS OR RELATIONSHIPS. • Interests of the following persons are to be treated as if they were yours: Any affiliation or relationship of your spouse, of your minor child, of a relative living in your immediate household or of anyone who is legally your partner that you are aware of, that would be covered by any italicized items above. • Other relationship, such as close personal friendship, that you think might tend to affect your judgment or be seen as doing so by a reasonable person familiar with the relationship.

Please note how last phrase about "Other relationship" was formulated. 141.211.44.143 16:53, 6 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

  • However, I think this is not workable. There is no way to disclose such COI other than providing your own name and a list of all your collaborators. This is inconsistent with current privacy policy. Besides, this only applies to editing about a person. COI with regard to a scientific subject, for example, would be a lot more tricky. For example, what if I include a reference to an article/book published by a person covered by COI above? This is something debatable. 141.211.44.143 17:08, 6 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

I definitely support the proposal made by FT2 that is focused on the only right thing: get the information about connection between editor and the topic. User:PhL38Fr 15:00, 12 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Many thanks for this discussion. I'm always grateful for concrete, practical ideas to address issues of concern. FT2 - I especially call you out on this. You are always coming up with good ideas that are always worth considering, and you propose actual language, which I find helpful in thinking out the issue. I believe some of the issues discussed above might be addressed in part in some alternative language that we just posted yesterday in response to concerns expressed during this consultation, including this discussion. You can find that language here. A combination of Option 1 and 2 may address the crux of the issues under discussion in this thread. I will be interested in hearing your thoughts on this. Geoffbrigham (talk) 13:37, 13 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

I STRONGLY Disagree with FT2's revised proposal in this section. "Clive is a protester and activist, and as a voluntary activity he helps 'put the facts out there'. Even though unpaid and voluntary, and not an employee, he must disclose that he has a connection to the topic, if he makes edits relevant to his activism on our sites, because his edits could reasonably be seen as influenced by his advocacy role (even if they were in fact balanced)." I am against this. I am in favor of requiring paid PR flacks to have to divulge what they are doing and who they are working for. But ordinary people who aren't connected to any organizations being discussed in articles, are unpaid and just volunteering and might be involved in some activism, having to disclose this? I am very much against that! The purpose of this paid contributions amendment is to get rid of bias, institutional bias, from large organizations, governments, corporations, PR firms, paying people money to "spin" information favorable to their POV on sites like Wikipedia. But on any issue that is controversial, people will be activists, on both sides of an issue. People who are unpaid activists just volunteering, that is a very common activity that many people on both sides of any issue will do. Those are people who are motivated, motivated enough to contribute to Wikipedia. If we don't allow them to contribute openly we'll be censoring the ability of common people to express themselves and post factual information on sites like Wikipedia. Most people ARE strongly opinionated, but most people are also capable of putting their opinions to the side and trying to write from a Neutral Point Of View (NPOV). However, there will still be a bit of bias that leaks through despite this. My concern with this revised proposal by FT2 is, it goes after the wrong people. The original proposal, the one that everyone is voting on higher up in the page, is a much better proposal, and one that I support, since it goes after the right people, the people who are being paid to spin, being paid by moneyed interests to change articles on Wikipedia to better represent the views of their clients, who, by definition, have money, since their clients are paying them to edit Wikipedia, after all. Given the extreme disparities in wealth, the income inequality, we see in the world today, the original proposal is following the right approach... follow the money. FT2's approach is wrong, and goes after a common person involved in a little unpaid activism just as vigorously as a PR consultant for a large corporation. A much better approach is to go after the PR flack for big business, while letting common people who aren't being paid and just involved in unpaid activism, not have to disclose any of this. Activism is such a broad and ill-defined category. Personally speaking, I have been involved in a very very small amount of activism, occasionally showing up at activist protests on very rare occasions, never at all being paid, and spending very little of my time (less than a fraction of 1%) on activism, and never being involved in any decisions undertaken by an activist organization. Should I have to disclose this? That would be ridiculous, given my very low level of involvement! But what about someone who is a full-time activist? Well, for someone to be an activist full-time, they would have to be getting money from SOMEWHERE, so that they can pay the bills. So I think, full-time activists, professional activists, they generally DO receive some type of financial compensation, or else they wouldn't be able to afford to do what they do. So those people ARE covered under the main proposal everyone is voting on. But I take great offense to the idea that someone like Clive from FT2's last example would have to disclose that he has a connection to the topic. It is quite frankly ludicrous. If people like him start having to disclose fairly loose ties to a topic, to me we have already fallen down a slippery slope, to the point where almost everyone has to disclose even the smallest, most incidental connection to any topic they edit an article about. But if we just focus on people who are being financially compensated for their contributions to projects like Wikipedia, that is a much smaller and much more well-defined, easily identifiable group of people. Anyway, sometimes people attending protests don't even agree with what the "leaders" of the protest are saying, and might just be at the protest out of curiosity or boredom, having nothing better to do. I have an example of this myself. I was at a protest in December, to raise the minimum wage. I found out, when I was at the protest, that the protest was part of a nationwide campaign that was calling to raise the minimum wage to $15 an hour. That is ridiculous! I think it should be about $10 an hour or maybe $11, but $15 is too high. Currently it is $7.25. Anyway, I didn't even agree with the protest, despite being at the protest and participating in it, since I didn't find out about it wanting the minimum wage at such a high level until it was too late and I'd already been there like half an hour or something. And I talked to some other people there and they also thought, maybe $15 an hour is going a little too far, even though, officially, that is what our protest was in favor of doing. Also I have worked for companies and actually worked for companies I hated and couldn't stand at all... and if I were writing on Wikipedia about them I wouldn't be biased in favor of my employer at the time but rather against it. Anyway my point is, it's hard to tell what someone's bias will be, sometimes it can be the opposite of what you might expect. And FT2's proposal is way too overly broad and would affect a very large percentage of people who ought not to be affected, many of whom would only have a very minor, passing connection to a given topic. As an example, since I attended that protest about the minimum wage of $7.25 an hour being too little money to live on and needing to lift it, but I also opposed the protest leader's goal of raising it all the way to $15 as something that would go too far, well, I would probably have to disclose this, under FT2's proposal, if I edited any article having to do with the minimum wage, as a topic. And that is simply ridiculous, I should not have to disclose such a silly little minor detail. FT2's proposal does go in the right direction but it simply goes way too far and ensnares too many people in the net of having to disclose small, minor, insignificant ties to topics. The current proposal people are voting on is a much better compromise, although personally I think PR flacks working for large corporations ought to be BANNED completely from editing Wikipedia. So in one sense FT2 goes too far (going after WAY too many people), and in another sense FT2 doesn't go far enough (not even REMOTELY punitive enough on the worst offenders). We need a much more intelligent, targeted approach than what FT2 says, and going after people who are paid to contribute to Wikipedia is the by far the best distinction about who to go after and who NOT to go after, that I can think of. That is exactly what the original proposal people above are voting on does. FT2's flawed revised proposal is a step backwards from that, in the wrong direction. --Yetisyny (talk) 03:32, 15 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Thank you Yetisyny for taking the time to comment. How do you feel about the alternative options presented, which are a bit more narrow in scope? You can find them here. Geoffbrigham (talk) 13:05, 19 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Support[edit]

I strongly support this measure, as it adds to the 

transparency which makes Wikipedia such a valuable resource. Sheena Ford

I too support transparency as it relates to paid contributions


I support transparency in paid contributions as it would add to my trust of the information's accuracy I read on this site, and I use this site every day. 173.251.49.18 18:20, 11 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Support[edit]

Yes I think their must be some type of accountability for sure. However, don't say that Wikimedia is all about truth, for instance, look up the definition of 'evolution' and you will see my point. Evolution has not been proved in the slightest and yet on the definition page you state it as a fact and not a theory. Ask any top DNA expert, and related scientists and they will tell you that they have no evidence, and that they can't prove it. People tout the word as a scientific word so it should be kept to scientific standards and have provable, reproducible results. I know everybody likes to fool themselves but science actually disproves evolution and yet it is stated as fact when it surely is not. 70.109.146.84 16:36, 7 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

You have got to be kidding me. If you ask any top expert in the field of biology they will say that evolution is true and creationism is wrong. You say "ask any top DNA expert". OK. How about Richard Dawkins? He is an example of top expert in biology and genetics. Guess what? He believes in evolution. So, you are wrong. One of the ideas Richard Dawkins coined is the idea of "memes", which are similar to genes, except memes are ideas that evolve over time, as part of the language and culture of a society. If you look at Wikipedia itself, you will see that Wikipedia memetically evolved from humble beginnings as an experimental side-project to Nupedia into the #1 biggest information resource on the entire planet. Similarly, humans genetically evolved from humble beginnings, ancient ancestors that were single-celled organisms, into a complex multicellular life form with opposable thumbs, language, the ability of rational thought, and the ability to discover and invent things in order to help ourselves out in this world. Religion and creationism, those are memes, as is evolution. On Wikipedia, a place where memes are tested for accuracy and whether or not they accurately represent the real world, the meme of evolution was successful and the meme of creationism went extinct. This is likely what will eventually happen to the meme of creationism, in the minds of all of mankind, in the long run. Like the dinosaurs, creationism itself will go extinct. Devoutly religious people once believed the world was flat, and that the Sun revolved around the Earth. Nowadays, only a tiny fraction of 1% of people in the world believe in a flat Earth or that the Sun revolves around the Earth, and while devout religious people still exist, their beliefs are quite different from devout religious people who lived during the Dark Ages. Someday, the same thing will happen to the idea of creationism, which is just as absurd as the idea that the world is flat, and contradicts known science just as much. On all 3 of these matters, namely whether the Earth is flat or round, whether the Sun revolves around the Earth or the Earth revolves around the Sun, and whether evolution or creationism is correct, Wikipedia is an accurate, reliable information resource, whether you like it or not. And Wikipedia ended up as a reliable and accurate information resource because that is what it has evolved into over time, with the percentage of information in its articles that is accurate gradually increasing over time, year after year. The debate taking place right here on this page is a part of that memetic evolution of Wikipedia, part of its continuous process of improvement. Wikipedia has identified a foreign object in its body, namely people paid to edit it and posting biased or inaccurate information on it, and is now reacting to solve the problem, similar to how the human body's immune system identifies a foreign object inside the body and produces antibodies to destroy it. This is actually helping to prove Richard Dawkins' theory of memetics, which is adapted from Charles Darwin's theory of evolution, correct. And that, in turn, leads to even more overwhelming evidence in favor of evolution. Of course, a creationist could simply state, "Jimbo Wales created Wikipedia, and he gazed upon it, and he saw that it was good. And on the seventh day he rested." But that would grossly oversimplify things, because, for one thing, Jimbo Wales is only one out of countless hundreds of thousands of people who have edited Wikipedia and helped it evolve into a more advanced information resource. This would make Jimbo Wales akin to the first cell of a multicellular organism, before cell division starts taking place, rather than akin to a creator god. Although I am sure there are those who would think otherwise... wiki-creationists, I call them, as opposed to wiki-evolutionists like myself. According to the wiki-evolutionist view which I hold, Wikipedia holds a natural niche in the online ecosystem of memes and ideas, and if Jimbo Wales had not started it, a similar wiki site would have been started by somebody else and evolved in its place. Wiki-creationists, on the other hand, would argue that Wikipedia or any site like it would only be possible if created by Jimbo Wales, and they would argue that he is a God-like figure who is unlike other men, and that if he had not started Wikipedia, a similar website would NOT have arisen to take its place. This debate can only be settled one way: by building a time machine, going back in time, and preventing Jimbo Wales from starting Wikipedia, then going back to the future and seeing what happened. Therefore, I have started work on construction of a time machine, so that I can use it to go back in time, prevent Jimbo Wales from starting Wikipedia, go back to the future, and observe the presence of a similar wiki enyclopedia online that would likewise be the world's #1 online information resource. If successful, I will be able to prove wiki-evolution correct, and therefore evolution by logical extension. Additionally, I will be able to go back in time even further, over 65 million years ago, have my photograph taken with a few dinosaurs, and prove biological evolution correct... that is, unless the dinosaurs eat me. Wish me luck! :-) --Yetisyny (talk) 05:32, 15 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Offenlegung von Zahlungen[edit]

für mich ist das ok, allerdings sehe ich auch Interessenskonflikte bei anderen Bereichen z.b. das einige Wikipedianer hier ihre wissenschaftlichen Arbeiten, Institute oder Stiftungen favorisieren. Daher bin ich der meinung das wikipedianer dies grundsätzlich auf ihrer wiki-seite offenlegen sollten wo sie tätig sind und waren um diese interessenskonflikte auszuschliessen.

Vielen Dank fuer deine Ueberlegung. Der Vorschlag waere eine erhebliche Ausweitung der Fragestellung und wuerde zudem mit dem grundlegenden ANON-Ansatz kollidieren. Beste Gruesse, --Jan (WMF) (talk) 17:17, 18 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Noble intentions, unintended consequences[edit]

I was quite involved in the WikiPR debacle on enwiki, and I've seen plenty of groups of paid editors. On one hand, especially when you're dealing with hundreds of accounts who all seem to be creating spammy articles, there is the reaction to ban the core behavior at play, namely paid editing. The issue with this proposal, however is it fails to account for the nuance and unintended consequences of such a restriction. While I'm hardly the world's largest paid editing advocate, this sort of misses the point. I more or less agree with Risker here. Most of the obvious/distinguishable paid editing I have noticed has been single purpose accounts creating articles on "Protechstartup" or "Bob Robertson, rising star". As a checkuser I tend to run into these accounts on singular ranges. We know they are a paid editing group, but who the hell are they? They could be WikiPR. Could be PR Corp. Could be Unemployed Freelancer. We have no clue, and how do we expect these people who have been socking prolifically to actually disclose. It's an aattempt to kick them off but there is still no way to actually prove that it is paid or COI editing. Sometimes I've run into editors who are editing their company's page (clearly COI) but not in a paid sense. They are doing so simply becuase they wish to. Oftentimes these edits improve article quality. Most of the paid editing that is obvious has been the creation of articles for non notable or barely notable persons. Raising notability thresholds would be the most sure means of quashing this sort of paid editing, not demanding disclosure. I've seen a few disclosed paid editors: the vast majority were reasonable, or tried to act reasonably. But this sort of WikiPR activity will not be stopped by these guidelines, and it risks tremendous instruction creep. How close is related. What is paid. How do I know the editors are paid. Is a SPA creating an article paid? Do we know if he's a single purpose or not? Do I have authority or obligation to run checkuser to see? This is an effort but this needs to be reframed "what if any actions should be taken" as opposed to the current proposal. NativeForeigner (talk) 20:10, 5 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

@NativeForeigner: Thanks for the thoughtful comments, and thank you for your effort on the WikiPR stuff. A few responses:
  • This is not an attempt to solve all paid-advocacy-editing-related issues in one swoop. As I see it, there are at least three different kinds of paid advocacy editors: lone wolves/freelancers; organized firms-for-hire; and in-house PR folks. I think you're right that this does very little about the first category (freelancers), since they are unlikely to care very much what the terms say and this is unlikely to be very useful in enforcement against them - if you can catch them, you have most of the tools you need to deal with them. For organized-firms-for-hire and in-house PR, I think it is more effective. They tend to have lawyers, investors, etc., and those people care what the terms say. Not to say that they are all scrupulous or moral, but this will at least put them on completely unambiguous notice that they need to think very hard about their business model and how they interact with the projects. That will help with the borderline or actually good-faith-but-don't-know-the-rules folks, and for the bad faith ones that go forward anyway, the amendment will make it easier for us to enforce the terms against them. (We think they are already pretty clear for this situation, but this will make it even better in this respect.)
  • For things like "editors who are editing their company's page without being paid to do that", I think Geoff has suggested elsewhere in the page that we narrow the definition a bit. We're still thinking about that.
  • We have just proposed some optional language that would address this concern. You can find it here. Thanks. Geoffbrigham (talk) 13:42, 13 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
  • I think implicit in your statement is that it is too hard to catch socks. I agree, and I hope we can invest in tech to help with that process. But I don't think "catching socks is hard" means we shouldn't improve other tools that we have to help deal with the problem once they are caught, or avoid investing in a little bit of communication to help reduce the number in the first place.
  • With regards to reframing as "what, if any, actions should be taken": there have been repeated discussions about a variety of proposals of varying complexity. All of them have failed to get consensus. This proposal is minimalist in part to avoid some of the difficult, real problems that those proposals died on. This isn't to say the proposal is perfect, and it shouldn't be the end of the discussion. But it is deliberately minimal in part so that it won't stop or interfere with other policies and proposals in the future - if we want to ban it altogether, or build better detection tools, or whatever - all of those are still possible after this change.
Hope that helps explain where we're coming from. —Luis Villa (WMF) (talk) 23:16, 5 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
It definitely does. I think the issue is there will be unintended circumstances which drives editors away, and although I think this would probably help with in house PR< it's so hard to identify what dedicated PR firms are running which accounts, it has limited impact there. Plus, from what I have seen generally CREWE efforts have been reasonably successful in dealing iwth in house PR, especialy for larger comparnies. Correct me if I"m wrong. NativeForeigner (talk) 00:00, 6 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
@LuisV (WMF) I think this statement: "As I see it, there are at least three different kinds of paid advocacy editors: lone wolves/freelancers; organized firms-for-hire; and in-house PR folks" fails to recognize the fourth, in my opinion, the most egregious type of paid advocacy editor--the employee or governor of an avowed "advocacy" organization. If the avowed mission of an organization is the advocacy of a POV, then by association any employee or governor of that organization who edits topics related to that mission is and should be considered a paid advocacy editor. Why does the focus of this amendment continue to be narrowly defined by commercial enterprise? The unintended consequences will be real when one class of paid advocate is given license by omission. --Mike Cline (talk) 21:42, 7 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
@Mike Cline: You make a point. Regardless I've rarely encountered that. NativeForeigner (talk) 08:51, 13 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Support for 3 options of disclosure.[edit]

While any reader should view any undocumented comment as suspect, disclosure of paid sponsership would aid readers' examination of the article.

=== Concern about proposal ===In truth money should not be the issue, joining the forum is a form of being at the arena, gladiator or not you will suffer consequences, that is just as is and cannot be changed if you support lies then you will be held accountable. Bequeathing power, authority and wealth has always been curtailed by God on either side of the coin it is open season."""" (WG) --Ecapaja (talk) 05:10, 6 March 2014 (UTC) One thing I do not like about this amendment is that the disclosure is mutual: my employer would know that I saw fit to use company time to edit this article or that article. I would find this to be chilling, and I might consider that my duty to correct errors, typos, etc. that I note in the course of my regular workday to be lessened accordingly. 64.85.169.79 21:23, 5 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

=== STRONGLY SUPPORT!! === x2 (me too)

In the interest of full disclosure and transparency, I support the amendment. The objections Ive read are IMO baseless. Professional journal articles require the same disclosure in order that a reader may evaluate possible conflicts of interest. Paid editing may help enhance any article for verity, but without disclosures,we lose ability to evaluate the content.

I do not object to editors with financial ties, as long as the ties disclosed. OTOH to restrict entries to amateurs, will IMO leave open the possibility of inaccurate or even hidden biased content with even less transparency. 71.48.107.64 23:02, 5 March 2014 (UTC) science consultant/educator in NJ[reply]

Strongly support[edit]

Let's not forget this is supposed to be an encyclopedia. There are no viable arguments made above that justify the use of paid contributions. For those being so literal as to worry about editing articles while at work for a completely unrelated profession/job, relax. We all understand that is not the purpose of this amendment. Please pass this amendment and maintain the integrity of Wikipedia.

Amendment Supported[edit]

I strongly support the amendment, which helps prevent Wikipedia from being used for public relations by private parties. Ianeds63 (talk) 01:15, 6 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

I also strongly support the amendment. Allowing non-disclosure of paid edits is essentially a small form of the disastrous Super PACs in American politics, that allow private wealth to influence the dispersal of information and what's more, to do so secretly.

Disagree / Desacuerdo[edit]

This amendment seems overreaching, particularly in terms of the examples it cites, such as the FTC. Laws regarding business fraud do not uniformly apply to information exchange that is not commerce, per se; damages would be extremely difficult to prove. Wikimedia would hope that the examples given extend to web forums and reference tools like Wikipedia; but the examples have a tenuous relationshi.

Addressing the demand side of this problem[edit]

I've voted oppose to this amendment, not because I am in favour of paid editing, but because I believe that trying to eradicate paid editing using the mindset that created this amendment will lead to witch hunts and wikilawyering. However I agree that there is a problem that needs to be addressed.

This amendment addresses the supply side of this problem, that there are editors and organisations such as Wiki-PR who are taking money to edit wikipedia; however no attention seems to have been given to why people are willing to pay for paid edits? If we can offer these individuals and organisations an alternative to paid editors, we can remove the financial incentive for paid editing. What is it that Wiki-PR been offering and how can we remove demand for it?

  • i)Article creation. The article creation wizard can be used as part of this deincentivisation, rather than discourage individuals and organisation because of COI we should direct them to this avenue as a matter of course. However any article so created will first be scrutanised for notability, neutrality, verifiabilty etc. If the article will be non-notable we should inform the individual/organisation so, that there is no way that they will have a wikipedia article paid or not, and any money that they are thinking of spending will be wasted. If however they are notable the article can be sent into a pool that volunteers can choose to edit and improve.
  • ii)Reputation management. First we should declare that we will not whitewash articles for the benefit of organisations, but also that we will also not allow contentious allegations to stand without verification, and we should be doing this anyway. If an organisation believes something is misleading, unfair or plain wrong we should educate them to the fact that they do not need to pay for {{POV}} and {{Citation needed}} tags. However there will be times when it can be proven that an individual or organisation has a genuine skeleton in the closet. We can discourage attempted whitewashing by making such attempts reputationally damaging, a press release of the attempt and a permanent record of people /organisations who have attempted to do so, a hall of shame in the manner of w:Wikipedia:Long-term abuse/List.

By working with the targets of Wiki-PR and its ilk, we can starve paid editors out of existence.--KTo288 (talk) 08:32, 6 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

I'm not sure that you understand what the LTA is about. that's for long term sock masters whose cases run back years and years, a decade for some, not for one-off paid editors. However I agree that there should be a separate place for that sort of thing. KonveyorBelt 17:21, 6 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
Sorry if I haven't been clear, the watchlist/blacklistid of any company that has found to have induldged in trying to remove verified details they find embarrassing, even for a first offense. The consequence of any attempt of trying to look better will result in further reputational damage.--KTo288 (talk) 15:30, 8 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
This... this is brilliant! In this reactive atmosphere of moral panic, especially after the Wiki-PR incident, we seem to be always tackling the symptoms of the problem rather than arriving at the root of the money source. Instead of trying the difficult way to solve a long and intractable problem (which might have collateral damage even), that is litigation against paid editing, why not try and deincentivize the reasons behind the payment and cash flow in the first place? TeleComNasSprVen (talk) 01:44, 8 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Why I am opposing-lack of data. Also, what are the motives behind this proposal?[edit]

I am opposing for lack of data on the long term effects of paid editing. This proposal, after all, only works if it can be proven that all paid editing is inherently harmful to the encyclopedia. Is it? I've yet to see any confirmation from the WMF, their legal team, or the leaders of the respective encyclopedia showing any proof. In fact, this amendment just might not be about paid editing at all. At #Who asked for this to be developed?, it is said that this amendment is a direct response to Wiki-pr saying that the TOU do not prohibit them from editing. Thus, this amendment can be construed as a "back atcha" to an individual firm, not a statement against general pad editing. In fact, we let undisclosed paid editors edit our pedias every day. Some of them make constructive edits. Most do. It's only the high profile cases of PR editing that stir trouble. And that's what this proposal is about. KonveyorBelt 17:23, 6 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Offenlegung von Auftraggebern und bezahlten Beiträgen[edit]

Grundsätzlich ist die Idee bezahlte Beiträge im Sinne der Nutzer auch als solche zu kennzeichnen sicher gut gemeint. Man sollte jedoch nicht so naiv sein zu meinen, das dies über eine freiwillige Selbstverpflichtung der Autoren der Beiträge auch tatsächlich in der Praxis funktioniert. Wikipedia ist in den letzten Jahren als Informationsquelle für den normalen User immer wichtiger geworden. Dies um so mehr als die letzten Verlage sich aus dem Geschäft mit Online-Lexikas komplett zurückgezogen haben. (Brockhaus) Da ist es natürlich sehr verlockend seine Produkte kostenfrei in einem Lexikon dezent zu plazieren, wo man von vornherein weiß das diese Platform von vielen Usern genutzt wird. Glaubt man den Recherchen der öffentlich rechtlichen Fernsehprogramme, so treten diese bezahlten Autoren nicht nur als normale Nutzer auf sondern als Autoren mit erweiterten Berechtigungen und Befugnissen. Außerdem benutzen diese Leute nicth nur einen Nutzernamen sondern gleich einige Dutzend davon, um auch aufkeimende Diskussionen in ihrem Sinne und unter verschiedenen Namen zu beeinflussen. Ehrlich gesagt, mir ist nicht klar wie Wikipedia dieses Problem mit einer freiwilligen Selbstverpflichtung in den Griff bekommen will. M.E. hilft hier nur ein gesundes Mißtrauen, eine gute eigene Allgemeinbildung und Informationen aus verschiedenen Quellen zu vergleichen um Artikel kritisch zu hinterfragen und evtl. Manipulationen auf die Spur zu kommen.Mars2030 (talk) 19:26, 6 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Since the possibility of finding the place I would like to be working in this editing page is quite remote, given the limitations of this UI and my knowledge of it, I am just putting my remark here and counting upon some "refactoring" editor (who might be paid!) to move it to a better home. (Please remove the foregoing sentence plus this one.)

I do not think the real worry here is about "editing." It is about the creation and modification of content in an influenced manner. The pharmaceutical industry requires authors of papers to disclose financial relationships that in any way might constitute a conflict of interest. What are the two parties in potential conflict? They are financial gain and unbiased truth, i.e., they are worried about influence. We know the researcher might have an actual opinion or outlook that affects his interpretation of results, but we want *his* opinion, not the opinion of some hidden party with business or political motives using him as a puppet. Influence is the issue, not pay. The teacher changing a mistake on a chemistry-related page is being paid. However, he would have been paid anyway. He was not influenced by his pay check. I think if some kind of definition can be worked out with language about "compensation for the purpose of intellectual influence on Wikipedia content," or some such wording, it will eliminate most of the neutral cases that unnecessarily complicate this matter. --Jkshrews (talk) 22:38, 6 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

The opener Mars2030 of the topic has absolutely right. Its not possible to find the truth unless everything is optional and not with a law that has teeth, zähne ;) It seems that this discussion is all just about to take away the responsibility of the organization and to give it only to the users or better the anonymous mass. Perhaps an intelligent way of business but a very poor sign for morality and ethics. --93.184.26.78 15:09, 15 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
Der Vorschlag beinhaltet keine freiwillige Selbstverpflichtung, sondern stellt eine rechtsverbindliche Offenlegungspflicht dar. Beste Gruesse, --Jan (WMF) (talk) 17:19, 18 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Alternate recommendation[edit]

First, appreciation to the Foundation and to commenters for taking this on. It's pretty clear from the discussion that there is a lot of support for the idea that we need to be vigilant against COI editing caused by "paid contributors" in particular, and general support (or at least only rare opposition) to the idea that the TOU should be tightened to explicitly forbid trying to fly under the radar about it. However, there is a lot of disagreement between community members what precisely "paid editing" includes. A PR flack paid to whitewash an article or create one for a nonnotable entity = clearly bad; professional expert editing freely with no employer coercion or direct oversight in area of professional expertise = probably ok. There is also disagreement by project how specifically vigilant we need to be (en:wp = high concern; wikisource/data/commons = less so; wikivoyage = more nuanced). How about the following alternative:

  • Each wikiproject should develop a clear project-specific policy on what constitutes a potential COI, including a prescribed way editors with a potential COI should disclose it (may range from "don't edit" to "make sure you indicate COI on talk page" to "mark every edit with a specific tag"). This provides the needed flexibility by project.
  • The Foundation amends the TOU to explicitly forbid COI editing in violation of each project's specific policy. This provides the additional "weaponry" to combat COI by omission of disclosure or misrepresentation that would apparently be helpful.
  • The Foundation develops a default COI policy which applies to wikiprojects which do not develop one of their own. This provides a backstop.

The difference versus the current proposal would be that instead of the Foundation prescribing a "strong minimum" disclosure policy (which a significant number of contributors are finding variously too weak or too strong), the Foundation would merely provide the framework for projects to combat paid-editor and other COI effectively within their requirements. Thoughts? Martinp (talk) 23:21, 6 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Hello Martinp, this is an interesting consideration. My initial concerns would be that this process is less clear for outsiders -- it may make it more difficult to explain the minimum rules for disclosure. I will think about this further, but thanks very much for the suggestion. Best, Stephen LaPorte (WMF) (talk) 20:54, 7 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
Hello Martinp, I drafted an addition to the policy following this idea. See it below at Allowing projects to write an alternative disclosure policy. Thanks, Stephen LaPorte (WMF) (talk) 01:09, 19 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Biased editing is not a problem, but the very foundation of Wikipedia[edit]

Paid editing is just one of many forms of biased editing. In fact it is a smaller issue than intrinsically motivated POV warriors, because PR-professionals charge for their time and therefore can't invest as many time and resources as those who are fighting for their believes. Since the very beginning of Wikipedia we all are justifiable proud about our ability to build a NPOV-article out of conflicted positions. It is the very foundation of our collaboration that we see opposed opinions not as threat but as valid contribution and strive to integrate them into a neutral description. Paid interest are just one more of those opinions. We are used to deal with biases and we are good at it.

If some are concerned that Wikipedia might be flooded by too many articles to be maintained and neutralized by our volunteers, we can always raise the threshold of notability and delete articles about small companies, products of little market share and the like. I admit issues with tourism destinations, they are notable but highly at risk of paid advocacy. But we will find methods to keep them free of undue content; we have done so for more than 13 years now and even in much more contested areas. --h-stt !? 13:24, 7 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Hi H-stt, thanks for your comment. So, if I'm reading your comment correctly, you would be against adapting the proposed amendment, correct? Take care. Geoffbrigham (talk) 18:17, 12 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
@Geoffbrigham: You bet, I oppose the amendment. I don't see paid editing as a more damaging issue than any other biased editing. And we are good in dealing with biases. --h-stt !? 17:29, 14 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
h-stt, how would you feel about an amendment that links to sock puppetry instead. Roughly, something like this:
"If you are accepting compensation in exchange for making contributions to Wikimedia projects, you may not engage in sock-puppetry; specifically, you may not create new accounts to avoid detection; use another person's account; use multiple accounts and present them as different users; or employ other people to use accounts to appear as unaffiliated contributors. Applicable law, or community and Foundation policies and guidelines, such as those addressing conflicts of interest or unfair business practices, may further limit or prohibit paid edits to a Wikimedia Project or require disclosure of affiliation and payment. For more information, please read our background note on disclosure of paid contributions."
Thanks, Geoffbrigham (talk) 11:38, 15 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
@Geoffbrigham: That would not be compatible with WP:ANON, one of the foundations of Wikipedia. Sock puppets are perfectly fine to separate editing in different fields or just for fun. One just may not use several sock puppets in one discussion or even vote. I still wonder, why WMF, Jimbo and many others are focusing on paid/compensated editing as an issue? Fans of soccer clubs, those with political or even philosophical believes can be just as biased. But they are intrinsically motivated, meaning they will invest their own time and energy in "setting things right" in Wikipedia. Paid editors are spending their client's time and money and thus are far less likely to be persistent, when they encounter resistance. When I write about listed buildings in my home town, I do that because I believe in their cultural value for society. Am I biased about them? Of course. And that's perfectly fine. If someone writes about their favorite movie, game or cell phone they might be biased too. And the article might show it. So what, then someone else comes in to tune it down a bit and neutralize it. Same for paid PR. I really don't get the obsession. --h-stt !? 15:11, 15 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
Thanks for taking the time h-stt in responding. You are raising good issues. We set out some of the reasons for the proposal above at the beginning of this talk page and in the FAQs. Also we have seen significant volunteer resources used to patrol against deceitful paid advocacy editing, and one argument is that it is not sustainable as more people seek to make money on Wikipedia and its sister sites while relying on volunteer teams to find and correct mistakes of undisclosed paid editors. That said, I hear your points: bias may be found anywhere and is not linked just to financial compensation, and that the edit, not the editor, should matter. In partial response, we have proposed a couple of options that narrow the focus of the amendment to try to put more of the emphasis on the edit and not the editor; and to limit the scope to the most problematic edits (and leave the rest as in the past without an express requirement of disclosure in the TOU). See here. I don't think this will satisfy you completely, but it gives you an idea of the gist of the thinking and a willingness to try to find other solutions. In any case, the Board will read this discussion. We are not counting votes per se, we are listening to ideas and feedback. Stronger arguments will have great weight, and the Board will make a decision accordingly. Your comments will no doubt help them think this through as well. Thank you again for your time. Geoffbrigham (talk) 18:02, 15 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
@Geoffbrigham: As I wrote above: If Wikipedia lacks the contributors to maintain NPOV, we should raise the notability levels and delete articles on smallish companies and their products. And I repeat on this issue again that it by no means depends on whether a biased editor is paid / compensated for his or her contributions. --h-stt !? 19:49, 17 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

I think the amendment is a good idea.[edit]

I think the amendment is a good idea, because it discloses the potential motives and bias of a contributer.

Better Disclosure for Paid Deletors and Obfuscators Appointed as Supervising Editors For an Article[edit]

Support the change wholeheartedly. But a related problem are 'official' editors who are paid to camp around sites like 'carbon price' 'fossil fuels' 'nuclear power' 'climate change' 'deforestation' 'pollution' 'arms dealers' 'surveillance' etc to delete information that is not in their client's interests, to make sure that debates expressed therein remain full of doubt. Not just MNCs but government secret services are doing this on wikipedia.NimbusWeb (talk) 20:52, 7 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Uneingeschränkte Zustimmung zu den vorgeschlagenen Änderungen[edit]

Sie dienen der wissenschaftlichen und damit auch einer gesellschaftlichen Redlichkeit. Montigny-le-Roi (talk) 21:26, 7 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Vielen Dank, Montigny-le-Roi. Beste Gruesse, --Jan (WMF) (talk) 17:21, 18 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Uneingeschränkte Ablehnung zu den vorgeschlagenen Änderungen[edit]

Es riecht, um nicht zu sagen, es stinkt. Geld beherrscht die Wahrheit, nicht umgekehrt. Und alles, was Gegenmeinung zu den Großen ist, findet keinen Platz mehr.

Thanks for your view against paid editing. To be clear, this amendment does not endorse paid editing. You can read more here. Take care. Geoffbrigham (talk) 18:14, 12 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

I support it.[edit]

If it means stopping the biased reporting and editing from some contributors, count me in. BrothaTimothy (talk) 22:53, 7 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

I think it is important to distinguish between the people who voluntary contribute and people who get paid for their contribution to Wikipedia! because it help to Wikipedia users to judge better about the accuracy and bias of the shared info! --Pari Sima

Oppose[edit]

I think it is a moot point because unenforceable; with so many mobile devices available around the world, anyone can edit anything at will. But I also think there is a question of integrity involved - WikiMedia's: the very act of adding such an amendment would, de facto, condone paid-contributions to articles. Shir-El too (talk) 00:06, 8 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

By this logic ("with so many mobile devices") one can not enforce WP:SOCK. Let's not bury our heads in the sand. An elephant in the room? Yes, there is indeed elephant in the room, and it is huge. 24.11.55.66 15:13, 8 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Support[edit]

Even though it will certainly not be enforced in 99.99% of the cases I believe the new requirement makes sense because it will give Wikimedia stronger ground in enforcing the most significant, in their viewpoint, 0.01%.

Good paid authors will be able to build better credibility and recognition this way so it will be useful for the good-faith paid authors as well.

I would consider adding some legalese though that would protect Wikimedia from potential accusations in non-even-handed or otherwise irregular enforcement because any attempt to make it such will probably drain all their resources and then some.

I strongly support this. 121.44.173.5 04:15, 8 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

I think it is important to distinguish between the people who voluntary contribute and people who get paid for their contribution to Wikipedia! because it help to Wikipedia users to judge better about the accuracy and bias of the shared info! --Paris 60.241.87.102 09:13, 9 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Support[edit]

The underlying idea for Wikipedia is that people will operate with good will. Working for somebody to push one or another point of view subverts the whole process. 24.136.187.187 06:04, 8 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Oppose[edit]

There's too many rules that are currently unenforceable. Creating more will solve nothing. We need less rules, not more. Jamesena (talk) 11:39, 8 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Oppose[edit]

Paid text is a big problem for WIKI. WIKI text demonising a prominent researcher into AUTISM, whose work has been validated many times, indicates the size of the challenge. It appears to me that the text in question has come straight out of the marketing department of a well known industry. Further, WIKI contributors have complained that the text in question is ring-fenced. WIKI has a proud heritage. However, unless it gets a handle on this quickly, it will increasingly lose credibility and enter decline, possibly to be replaced with a more robust structure. The proposal in question cannot be enforced and diverts attention from a more pressing concern.Laplumedematanteestdanslejardin (talk) 19:32, 8 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Just to be clear, the proposed amendment does not endorse paid advocacy editing. You can read more here. Thanks. Geoffbrigham (talk) 18:10, 12 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

In Favor of paid editing for all articles![edit]

"the proposed amendment makes clear that "community and Foundation policies, such as those addressing conflicts of interest, may further limit paid contributions or require more detailed disclosure." This provision gives the community discretion to further limit paid editing, including paid advocacy editing, according to the needs of the specific project. That is, the proposed amendment is a minimal requirement, but the community may impose greater restrictions or bans." Was pretty much the encompassing end statement on the main page pertaining to the proposal. I feel that others are correct that it would be good in a sense to be able to know that someone with more knowledge pertaining to a subject would make this a better site provided that the paid entries disclosed the information at the TOP of the page not the bottom, and that the disclosures are investigated by your team to the best of their knowledge by asking for support from possible competitors. This could of course open a new investigation department and more jobs within Wiki. I for one would like to see Wiki become a more fact based site as opposed to just anyone being able to edit content. Therefore, should Wiki decide to let a paid disclosure be submitted one could then feel secure that it not only was investigated but had also allowed competitors to make any amends and continue to do so. To avoid a he said she said; this competitor edit would have to submit the information, ( with full disclosure as to if they are being paid to make such an edit) which would then be investigated by your team before the edit can transpire and then a wiki representative edit can be made. I understand completely; the more I think on it how sticky this could be, but on the other hand I would like to see Wiki become a very fact based source that I can count on and trust your judgement to keep it like an encyclopedia and not an advertisement dumping ground.~ TPowers Lady of Dunan


It would help promote effective writing and attract a more skilled group of writers to the site. So it would also stand to reason that access to the site should be restricted to paying customers as if Wikipedia had been akin to your neighborhood newspaper for instance. With paid writers you would get a new kind of professional quality you just can not get taking in unknown volunteers.

I would also say this would benefit the writer in other ways such as employment. A paid writer could file taxes like any other man or woman in the work force and take full credit for their useful labor within the site. You could even use it as an excuse for establishing users true identities so that when a vandal or group of vandals hits a particular page you can sue them just like someone crashing into your automobile because they ran a red light on the freeway.

In regard to keeping things undisclosed I am against on the grounds that if you are a sales associate at a major retail chain you are not afforded secrecy if you get fired for screwing up on the job. The employer goes will out of their way to ruin that persons life and career so that they never even get a job selling used cars and the same should be true of paid writing. The writer screws up they should be given a bad reference the rest of their natural lives so that they can not pollute the market with inferior labor!

The non-wiki community would also take an interest in paying for information they know for a fact is correct rather then taking some high school kid's word for it, who is not even paid for their time and cannot be held accountable for their actions.

When I was going to a private high school no English teacher no matter the grade level took Wikipedia seriously mentioning just how easy it was to vandalize the site before our eyes. I used Wikipedia as a source one time in American history and you know what the teacher told me in front of the class? She said "You'll never get to college learning from computer literate vagrants! Why not a good book instead of wasting my time and your parent's money!"

That's all I have to say concerning this! 96.2.110.63 23:05, 8 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

I agree. Writers and editors should be paid according to their skill level and expertise. Wikipedia has no value as it is, and your defense of it and its bogus ethos is ridiculous. Their is no trust with amateur entry writers, and no guarantee of accuracy or quality. The only positive of that is it hopefully has allowed some professional encyclopedias to remain in business. The fact that you have destroyed some is utterly heinous. I have carefully composed entries only to have them ruined by amateur editing. What are you upset about? If you think it renders the entries as advertising, rewrite them! The idea that this is valuable and can be continually rewritten renders it worthless. No professor worth anything will allow students to use wikipedia. Its only value is in spreading knowledge to those too poor or rural to have access to a library. But what good is the knowledge if it is corrupted by ignorance? That is your problem, not paid writing. OOPS! I thought this was about wikipedia, not wikimedia. What the hell is wikimedia???? 98.140.79.240 03:51, 9 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

  • Yes, absolutely. We must attract more skillful paid editors. They should simply make disclaimer of financial COI on their user page (as proposed in current version of this instruction) and go ahead. Everyone will appreciate their good faith effort in the project, and I know that many paid editors do just that. 24.11.55.66 16:56, 9 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Wikipedia has plenty of value in the hands of people with a degree of reason; "person A says X" does not mean that X is true, but neither is it a valueless statement. Just check your sources - Wikipedia makes that extremely easy. It sounds like you'd be better off paying for a subscription to a service with a radically different business model. 81.96.200.247 22:49, 10 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

I don't agree. Paid writers work for money and in many cases they do this all the time (whole work-day and year round). In some respects - especially the parts, that get better if they are practiced very much like ortography, writing style this leeds to higher quality.

In other respects, it reduces quality, as doing the same thing all day and year round leeds to boredown. Second to earn enough money, one has to write very much, therefore there isn't the time to do a lot of research for every article. Third there may be paid editors, that are paid for promoting lies or unbalanced articles. (Of course some paid editors may write very good and balanced articles too.)

But this is not what the "Paid contributions amendment" is about. We don't want to forbit it, we don't want to promote it, we only want that paid contributers tell that they are paid contibutors. In some cases this may be good, in others it may be bad.

--Kersti (talk) 09:13, 12 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Strongly oppose[edit]

We need to suppose that every editor has his own concerns in items he contributes to. Our rules should regulate the quality of the content of Wikipedia etc. INDEPENDENTLY on identity and private motivation of the contributors who invest their time, their work, their knowledge, their skills, their facilities or their money in improvement of Wikimedia projects.

If the user write with bias, subjectivelly or unencyclopedicly, he should be corrected (or even blocked if he heavily harms the project) regardless his motivation. If the user inserts valuable and quality contributions, he should be appreciated and welcomed independently on his private relations outside Wikimedia projects. We have no justifiable reason (nor a real authority and possibility) to inspect private motivation and private contracts of our contributors. --ŠJů (talk) 01:58, 9 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

I would agree with you if Wikipedia community was able to efficiently correct the quality of content, i.e. fix intentional misinformation. But this is not possible, as honestly stated in our Official risk disclaimer. In practice, many subject areas of the project can be easily highjacked by a small group of paid editors coordinated from a single center, and I edited in one of such subject areas. Not any more. 24.11.55.66 16:42, 9 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
The risk of intentional misinformation is in every edit, whether paid or unpaid. Every editor has his own preferences, concerns, opinions, contacts, limits... there is no justified reason to have special restrictions just for paid editors. --ŠJů (talk) 01:15, 10 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
Paid editing violates the basic assumption that every editor represents himself. If several people edit as proxies for the same organization or person who hired them, the key policy of WP:Consensus can be easily used as a tool for promoting whatever POV the employer wants them to promote. Worse, a group, coordinated from a single center, can be used to attack and get rid of "undesirable" contributors they do not want to see around. This is not a fantasy, but something I actually read long time ago in an interview given by people involved in such business, although they did not mention specifically Wikipedia. The interview was given to Novaya Gazeta. Right now, this newspaper had to close all discussions on their site because of massive comments by paid trolls. 141.211.44.143 17:06, 11 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
I don't see how Wikipedia's policies on sockpuppetry and meatpuppetry do not already address some of the concerns that you have. An operator having one or more accounts trying to game a discussion is not that much different from one employer having one or more "hired persons" trying to game a discussion. You can proxy just as well with sockpuppets and meatpuppets, and they'd be blocked by Wikipedia all the same. Bear in mind also that other Wikimedia wikis are also affected by the scope of this proposed change, who may be more in favor of "paid editing" than others, and not just English Wikipedia which could arguably handle this at a local level. TeleComNasSprVen (talk) 11:54, 12 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Incompréhensible[edit]

"Il est extrêmement probable qu'une contribution rémunérée, mais intentionnellement non déclarée comme telle, ne contribuera pas, positivement et honnêtement, à l’intérêt du public." Cette phrase extraite sous le titre "Existe-t-il d’autres effets négatifs possibles pour les contributions rémunérées ?" est 'étonnante' pour le moins. Une proposition au sens phrase correctement énoncée est soit juste soit fausse soit indécidable. Si elle est fausse il faut le prouver et elle doit être corrigée ou retirée, si elle est juste elle est acceptable à condition de fournir sa preuve de justesse si elle est indécidable marquée comme telle avec preuve. La phrase suivante " ... ne contribuera pas, positivement et honnêtement, à l’intérêt du public." implique une notion de bien ou de mal spécifique de la chrétienté qui se doit de tout cataloguer en bien ou en mal afin d'asservir les personnes, au sens les marquer comme dans la famille - amis ou hors donc ennemi. C'est une vue de l'esprit arbitraire, dogmatique et extrêmement violente. Le bien ou le mal, le positif ou négatif ne dit rien de l'intérêt de la chose contrairement à ce qui est déclaré. Le "négatif" tout autant que le positif peut ou non être intéressant, informatif. Chercher à classer arbitrairement et pour une justification difficile à défendre en bien ou mal, en positif ou négatif une proposition (une information) est hors du champ de la connaissance, des Sciences mais relève des jugements adossés à des dogmes. Un dogme, in démontrable injustifiable est la source la plus certaine de violence donc d'arbitraire et de désolation, d'exclusion, d’intolérance.

Pour résumer : chercher à qualifier une proposition (un texte informatif) comme positivement ou négativement relève du dogme (de l'arbitraire). Il est bien plus utile, au sens informatif, de se contenter de se limiter à déterminer sa justesse. La justesse étant démontrable. La complexité du réel est telle que ce dernier est inaccessible. Ceci rend donc toute proposition relative à la description du réel à jamais incomplète donc fausse car toujours partielle. Afin de palier à cet inexorable, une proposition sera donc établie d'un certain "point de vue" explicitement décrit. C'est ce que fait la Science en décrivant les limites du système étudié, le contexte, les grandeurs prises en compte. Le point de vue limite l'éclairage du sujet explicitement car il ne saurait en être autrement. La notion de positif ou de négatif est simplement sans objet dans une encyclopédie.

intentionnalité[edit]

Jamais il n'est possible de décrire exhaustivement ni de prouver l'intentionnalité d'un acte. Notre cerveau accumule tant les impressions, les réflexions les émotions que chercher les intentions ne peut être parfaitement défini. Il est donc inutile d'associer les qualités de l'auteur à un texte pour en déterminer l'intention afin d'essayer d'en qualifier la justesse. Il est par contre indispensable d'en valider la justesse. Et par là de proposer plusieurs points de vue sur un même sujet sans devoir choisir tel ou tel. Chaque point de vue peut apporter de l'information et par là intéresser une personne. Le marchand, puisque le sujet de cette réflexion-consultation est soucieuse de se protéger des marchands, peut défendre son point de vue tout autant que le consommateur, puisque c'est la problématique de cette discussion et qui n'est qu'un point de vue parmi bien d'autres de la manière dont s’élabore les textes.

Je propose que l'encyclopédie fasse l'effort d'adjoindre à chaque (la plupart) entrée des tableaux (ou autre moyen) apportant des points de vues différents pouvant être mis en perspective c'est à dire de montrer chacun un point de vue particulier et par là enrichir la connaissance d'un sujet.

Why do I need separate logins for Wikipedia and Wikimedia?????[edit]

I have an account at Wikipedia and have edited for many years. But that doesn't give me an account with Wikimedia. If I am invited to vote on this issue inside of Wikipedia, it makes no sense to me that I should have to resgister a new account for Wikimedia. This makes so little sense to me that I'm not going to waste my time with such an awkward arrangement. Either the vote should be within Wikipedia, or anyone with a Wikipedia account should automatically have a Wikimedia account with the same login.173.8.212.241

Quite possibly your account was created when the software for the Wikimedia Foundation did not support interlinking account information between separate wiki systems. This wiki, Meta-Wiki, is on a different domain name //meta.wikimedia.org than the English Wikipedia //en.wikipedia.org which would explain the disconnect between your user accounts. However, the introduction of Single-user login (SUL) tech around 2008 has allowed it so that you can merge your account information across the Wikimedia wiki family by visiting Special:MergeAccount. TeleComNasSprVen (talk) 04:35, 11 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Should fair use policy on English Wikipedia be modified to allow copyrighted logos to be displayed on user and project pages to communicate affiliations?[edit]

There is currently a request for comment at en:Wikipedia_talk:Non-free_content#RfC:_Non-free_images_in_collaborations_with_other_organizations.

One argument for doing this is that it can increase an organization's compliance with the policy discussed here, because displaying a copyrighted logo (perhaps with special permission throught OTRS) on a project page communicates an organization's presence on Wikipedia.

One argument against doing this is that it disrupts Wikimedia community values to minimize use of non-free content.

Comments are requested. I am posting here with the presumption that people commenting here might feel that increased use of non-free logos is a potential consequence of this paid contributions amendment. Blue Rasberry (talk) 22:13, 9 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Common submission from Swedish Language Wikipedia concerning the proposed Paid contributions amendment[edit]

In response to the Paid contributions amendment proposal to the Terms of use, (the proposal), discussion amongst users of Swedish Language Wikipedia occurred on Bybrunnen, primarily in Swedish. There is already a recommendation on Swedish Wikipedia that paid contributers declare openly their conflict of interest. The discussion centered on whether this should be a binding, mandatory rule or not. Multiple reasons were given for and against the proposal, and after these were listed users were encouraged to give their support either for or against the proposal during a voting period that continued from the 3rd to 9th of March 2014. During the period of voting eighteen votes were received against the proposal, with one neutral vote and no votes in favour of it. This participation level is similar to that experienced in deletion decisions and administrator elections. Both the reasoning and the votes are presented below, in English translation.

Reasoning[edit]

In favour of the proposal[edit]
  • It was suggested that the possibility of getting caught breaking the rules proposed would make companies aware of the risks of not declaring paid contributions.
Against the proposal[edit]
  • Concern was raised about the possibility of users being falsely accused, of the conflicts this would create and the feelings of those falsely accused. It was felt this would do more to worsen the climate on Wikipedia, and around Wikipedia in general, than benefit it.
  • Concern was raised about to which length Wikimedia Foundation would go to investigate whether a user had made undeclared contributions, and to which length Wikipedia would protect users wrongly accused.
  • Concern was raised about the wording whereby a contributor needs only to declare who he/she is in the employment of and of whom this company has been engaged. It was suggested that this alone would render the proposal ineffective as a company wishing to promote itself could employ a secondary company which then employs a PR company; this would result in a declaration similar to "I am John Smith, I work for John Smith PR, and we have been employed by Letter Box Company to conduct these edits."
  • Concern was raised about the multiple grey zones around what constitutes a "paid edit", with governmental, educational, organisational, sectarian and other types of editors possibly being involved, with or without pay.
  • Concern was raised about how WMF/Wikipedia could pursue any kind of suspicion of "paid edit" and make use of this amendment in an effective way. There is concern that this amendment would only turn out to be a cosmetic rule with minimal founding in actual practice.
  • Concern was raised about the effectiveness of this amendment, as most articles are open to non-registered editors.
  • Concern was raised about whether the mandatory marking of "paid edits" makes for discriminatory action against editors based upon their identity and not their edits.
  • Concern was raised about whether the mandatory marking of "paid editors" – on the other hand – would lead to an unnecessary large acceptance of editors with a clear conflict of interest.
  • Concern was raised about how Wikipedia's anonymity principle would be affected, and that requiring contributors to state their employer could scare away target groups Wikipedia has long tried to attract. This could include anyone who doesn't necessarily have fast working hours, but where giving information to the public is part of their work, for example a professor. In principle Wikipedia encourages these people to edit in their area of expertise.

Voting[edit]

Det gick att rösta till och med klockan 23.59 söndag den 9 mars 2014. Kommentera gärna din röst, antingen på svenska eller engelska.

For[edit]
Against[edit]
  1. Dieselmotorvagnar (till stationen) 3 mars 2014 kl. 05.55 (CET) For my comment in English se under Comments. På svenska: Ett fullständigt abderitiskt förslag som jag är helt och hållet emot.
  2. SergeWoodzing (diskussion) 3 mars 2014 kl. 06.41 (CET) People who are paid to contribute should behave even better than people who aren't paid, writing verifiable facts and providing reliable sources, otherwise whoever is paying is bound to be very dissatisfied when entries are removed. The anonymity factor is also important.
  3. Yger (diskussion) 3 mars 2014 kl. 06.51 (CET) Creates new complication and chase potential new contributers away
  4. Averater (diskussion) 3 mars 2014 kl. 09.35 (CET) As already stated in previous comments and also because, as is shown in the comments of those favoring the amendment, it will be used against others by users with a different point of view when proper arguments run out no matter if the others are paid or not.
  5. Rex Sueciæ (disk) 3 mars 2014 kl. 09.41 (CET) As above.
  6. Lavallen (mail) 3 mars 2014 kl. 10.09 (CET) Återkom när vi loggar in med bank-id
  7. ℇsquilo 3 mars 2014 kl. 11.34 (CET) a half-baked idea that will spread mistrust and misunderstanding in the Wikipedia community.
  8. Paracel63 (diskussion) 4 mars 2014 kl. 00.56 (CET) A misguided idea that will be impractical, unenforceable and counterproductive. Breaks some of Wikipedia's core principles.
  9. Janders (diskussion) 4 mars 2014 kl. 09.21 (CET) Bad idea. We shall focus on the quality and the published results, and not on how the contributors are working! The proposal focuses on one of the least serious of the many possible problems where Wikipedians can act in their own interest.
  10. Sjö (diskussion) 4 mars 2014 kl. 09.49 (CET) This will spread mistrust and misunderstanding in the community, further discouraging new editors from continuing. At the same time, it will offer almost no protection against paid editing, because of the possibility of anonymous editing and the general difficulty of provding evidence of paid editing. This seems to me to be a solution to a problem that exists mainly on the large language versions, such as the English Wikipedia. Smaller language versions, such as the Swedish one, can mostly recognise individual editors with an agenda and handle them accordingly. I also agree with Janders post above.
  11. Tostarpadius (diskussion) 4 mars 2014 kl. 10.11 (CET) SAA.
  12. Adville (diskussion) 4 mars 2014 kl. 11.12 (CET) - As Diselmotorvagn writes in the comment field below.
  13. FredrikT (diskussion) 4 mars 2014 kl. 12.23 (CET) (I agree with all the comments above. This is a BAD idea!)
  14. LPfi (diskussion) 4 mars 2014 kl. 12.44 (CET) The amendment would not solve any problem, especially as it is enforceable only when somebody already admits paid contributions. The problem it tries to target can be handled as any other COI edits. The amendment would be a severe threat to anonymous accounts, especially if WMF or the community tries to enforce it (which would require breaking anonymity), but also just by fear about such action and by antagonists having more incentive to break the anonymity. The worst effect will be on professors and the like, who would (with the current wording) no more be allowed to write about their speciality anonymously.
  15. Lixer (diskussion) 5 mars 2014 kl. 17.23 (CET) Som ovan / As above
  16. Tomas e (diskussion) 7 mars 2014 kl. 18.27 (CET) Exaggerated and impracticable, agrees with Paracel63, Sjö, LPfi and others.
  17. rrohdin (diskussion) 8 mars 2014 kl. 16.18 (CET) Impracticable
  18. Taxelson (diskussion) 8 mars 2014 kl. 23.53 (CET) As above
Neutral[edit]
  • NH 3 mars 2014 kl. 17.07 (CET) Kan varken rösta för eller emot. Jag har alltid tyckt att man ska undvika att redigera i artiklar där intressekonflikt kan uppstå. Och där ska tröskeln för vad som räknas som intressekonflikt vara mycket låg. Detta är en minoritetsåsikt, men jag håller mig ändå med den. Om vi hade en sådan riktlinje och menade allvar med den skulle frågan om betalda redigeringar vara ett ickeproblem.
That is to say, "Can not vote for or against. I have always thought that you should avoid editing the articles where conflict of interest may arise. And where should the threshold for what is considered a conflict of interest to be very low. This is a minority opinion, but I stick with it anyway. If we had such a guideline and was serious about it, the issue of paid edits be a non issue." At least that's what Google Translate thinks NH said. JimScott (talk) 14:56, 20 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
Comments[edit]

Längre kommentarer som stör röstningen kan presenteras i detta avsnitt.

Longer comments that disrupt the poll can be presented in this section.

I don't support the idea of people coming to Wikipedia having been paid simply to market their company, or dirty down another company. On the other hand, if a person has been paid to write a balanced and well written article about their company, their sports club, or anything else they're associated with – or even been paid by another company to do so – and does it, does succeed to create an article Wikipedia is happy to have, I see absolutely no reason to treat these users any differently to any other user. More troubling however, are the grey areas where employees of educational institutions, or archives, might be uploading images or working on articles 'on work time'; again, as long as these users contribute in the way neutral manner expected of all users, I see absolutely no reason, what so ever, to treat them any differently. To require these users to state details about their-self that they normally wouldn't is the same as to offend them, to spit in their faces and say 'we don't trust you, tell us what you're really up to'. No user should be treated this way, ever, let alone users who are giving us – the entire Wikimedia movement and every person who contributes to, and takes enjoyment of it – more than most other people ever will.

In no way does this proposal seem anything less than thoroughly thought through. At the same time it seems that doing the best for the Wikimedia Movement was not at the forefront of thought. The tools to attempt to dismiss any resistance have been cleverly hidden in the proposal. Unfortunately, the scant relic of anonymity which has been preserved in the proposal is nearly worthless. Requiring someone to state where they work, combined with the possibly small interest range they have (reflected in the small range of topics they edit in any serious matter), will easily lead work colleges, and imaginably even people further afield to the conclusion that Editor X is Person Y. With the threat of being 'outed' so easily, it would be entirely understandable if these persons refrained from editing Wikimedia projects in the future. This is an utterly disastrous outcome, as Wikimedia should, in my opinion, encourage editing from as many reliable sources as possible.

Alarmingly, the proposal's proposal page is heavily biased and lifts only the negatives that so called paid contributors bring without discussing the positives. Without discussing the how rich these people have made our media collection, Commons. Without discussing how much people like professors, who may or may not fall four of the proposal, have contributed, effectively 'in secret' to our articles. Indeed, the role these people have played for Wikimedia during its existence to date may never be known. Despite this, it seems certain people are ready to completely disregard these people and demand they state personal details they might not wish to share with the world. This is absurd; completely and utterly absurd.

Perhaps most alarming of all is the total lack of understanding around the proposal. Given the lack of information on the proposal, and that which exists being bias, it's not hard to understand why a lack of understanding has arisen. It seems unlikely that the proponents of the proposal have done any research to ascertain whether or not it will achieve what they're out after; and more alarmingly, what impact the proposal will have on all Wikimedia projects. With the prevailing lack of information, it is impossible to imagine how anybody can make an informed decision; let alone the Board of trustees.

It is disheartening to see that 'big wiki solutions', may be forced on all projects; regardless of size or even the problem existing. It is naive to believe 'paid editing' doesn't go on to some degree on most or all versions of Wikipedia; but it is handled in vastly different ways. The Swedish Language Wikipedia ranks in the top ten by number of articles, yet we keep on top of promotional edits through a team of dedicated and mostly unthanked users who, like hawks, patrol new edits and make sure that everything is as it should be. Other versions of Wikipedia, such as the German language version, require edits to be patrolled before they're accepted into the stable version of an article. That all projects could be forced to accept what largely feels like an English language solution to a problem they haven't got control over implies that they need new work methods, not the rest of us.

Indeed, it's hard to see how the proposal will even be effective. Certainly it may reduce, by an amount which given the lack of presented research is anybody's guess, promotional edits. The question, as alluded to in the previous sentence is, by how much? If it's a one percent reduction it certainly isn't worth alienating other user groups which could be affected by the proposal. If it's one hundred percent we still have to ask ourselves, is eliminating promotional editing really worth the damage it could do? Do we really want to scare people and institutions into not contributing, when they could share, with every one of us, immense resources? Anyone that thinks it's worth it seriously needs to think about why they're contributing to their respective Wikimedia project.

Given the general toothlessness of the proposal we seriously need to ask ourselves, why has it even got this far in this state? We risk losing potential contributors with rules that do little. On the proposal's page it's stated that a person need only their employer, affiliation and the client. If the employer is a PR-firm, the affiliation is employment only, and the client is another PR-firm, a letter box company, or a legal firm, what have we gained by disclosure? Nobody is any wiser as to who is actually paying for the edits, or what they're trying to achieve.
