Without this information how can anybody make a reasonable and sound judgement on whether the edit is worthfull or should be reverted immediately? Without the information it encourages people to jump to conclusions, you're being paid, you're now suspected of having an agenda to promote/discredit a company.

We must also ask ourselves, how will this proposal actually work? It relies on honesty, just as Wikimedia does currently. There are already laws in place in many jurisdictions which prevent activity of deceptive promotion; it is stupid to believe that a clause in the Terms of use requiring disclosure will lead to complete an utter honesty. What's left is what we have now. Accusations, right or wrong, of people having hidden agendas; with little we can do to prove (or disprove) them. What does Wikimedia Foundation intend to do to prevent people being wrongly accused (and defend them if they are)? Unfortunately, the general vagueness and lack of information around the proposal rears its ugly head again. It's quite simply not stated to which means Wikimedia Foundation will go to enforce this rule, and to defend those wrongly accused. I dread to think how much economic drain this would place on Wikimedia Foundation is they were to thoroughly investigate (and/or defend) all accused.

Put simply, the proposal as it stands now should never have gotten this far. There is a lack of information, and that which exists is skewed in favour of the proposal. Given that one of the pillars of Wikipedia, and all Wikimedia projects, is neutrality, this is alarming. The proposal in another form, with clearly defined rules and case examples, with information about its likely affects, and with assurances and extra information about the gigantic holes raised earlier, may get my support; as it stands I would be ashamed to support it. The people who currently support it need to take a long hard look at themselves and ask: 1) do I actually understand the implementations, or do I just like the sound of it? And 2) why am I supporting something that will drive away some of Wikimedia's most valuable contributors?

The proposal needs to be presented with more information, and with more refinement. Do it again, and do it right. Dieselmotorvagnar (till stationen) 3 mars 2014 kl. 05.55 (CET)

Comment about user signatures. Links in user signatures have been prefixed with sv: so that these point to the relevant page on Swedish Language Wikipedia as many of the users do not have pages on Meta. Dieselmotorvagnar (talk) 23:36, 9 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Thank you for sharing these detailed, organized, and helpful thoughts from the Bybrunnen discussion. –SJ talk  11:18, 10 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
I agree this is helpful, and appreciate the time and participation of everyone. We are thinking about an amendment with narrower scope in light of all the feedback in this extensive consultation. I don't think it will address all the above concerns, but it may mitigate some. We expect to be posting some of those alternative ideas in the next day or so. If you like or dislike them, I would be interested in hearing your views if your time permits. Take care, Geoffbrigham (talk) 18:02, 12 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Comment[edit]

I feel much more comfortable when I know if an article in Wikipedia is sponsored or not sponsored. Everyone has bias but it becomes much more critical when the bias is supported by money because it seems to me that the intent may well be more to promote rather than inform. The problem of making bias visible will not be resolved by this amendment but it is a step in the right direction.

I absolutely agree that people must disclose their affiliations when they write into Wikipedia, and mention if they have received monies. I do agre that wiki will lose credibility if this does not take place. In other dictionaries/encyclopedia, there is a list of contributors with their credentials, why should Wiki be different? It does not mean we have to say who we are, but what we are. I also agree with a proposal made in French above: articles should be more open to ideas from differing, divergent and even opposite standpoints: a new contributor could add that they disagree with what contributor A wrote, and this should not mean that the first contribution gets deleted, as long as the argument is honest and based on facts, or that the subjective aspect is well presented.At present, this is only possible with stubs. Long live Wikipedia!

MUCH SUPPORT!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Support[edit]

If someone is being payed money to edit Wikipedia, they should be required to disclose such, because it can help identify potential conflicts of interest. AnnerTown (talk) 03:49, 10 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Ofc, this is common sense - until you've to hide something. Prokaryotes (talk) 20:57, 10 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

My take - support change[edit]

Wikipedia has for long been a place where editors spam, push their POV, promote their business, it pays having your page or your links on Wikipedia! We constantly delete, revert and remove that type of obvious advertorial information. Until now, editors were not required to state that affiliation beforehand (though, quite some do!). In a way, it does not matter, if you continue to push your advertising/promotion/POV to Wikipedia, you will be reverted and in the end possibly blocked or even banned, whether you state your affiliation or not. However ..

.. there are several cases where editors were encouraged to state their affiliations, Wikipedia's GLAM is one of those initiatives, I've personally worked together with quite some of editors related to external databases. I feel that that works, editors come in, they convey their affiliations with a certain organisation, and work together with the community to improve Wikipedia on our terms. Of course, every now and then, there are also 'GLAM's (or similar) who fail to do so - in some cases, those have been met with reverts and even blocks, generally because it is unclear whether the editors are here to promote their organisation, or to help out Wikipedia (it is a grey area, but some are blatantly upfront about what their goal is: to be linked and to have their pages here!).

I've been active in spam-fighting on Wikipedia for a long, long time. If an editor comes in, states their affiliation, discusses or talks with others but edits a bit too promotional/POV, generally talking with them helps. No need for warnings, blocks, etc. Those who however come in and do not talk/discuss/state their affiliation and still edit too promotional/POV are generally met with early warnings, blocks and worse (however 'good' their affiliation is!).

Does this mean that everybody HAS TO state their affiliation: no, if you don't want to, you still don't HAVE TO - not stating your affiliations is not a blockable offense. Advertising your business or pushing your (paid) POV (against consensus) is what is the blockable offense.

I do believe that that type of transparency pays off, doing it behind the scenes is more prone to get stern warnings (or worse) than being upfront and responsive to concerns. I support the proposal to make this clear in the Terms of use, and I believe that it actually helps with your Wikipedia experience. --Dirk Beetstra T C (en: U, T) 09:26, 10 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Strong support but suggested change[edit]

As others have noted, having the affiliation info on the actual Wiki page (not the users page) would enhance transparency tremendously...173.61.197.234 20:11, 10 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Idenficação pela própria Wikipédia dos produtores dos artigos pagos[edit]

Uso a Wikipédia eventualmente e percebo a sua importância para a cultura, tendo ela substituído as enciclopédias tradicionais. Assim, parece-me uma conduta criminosa substituir a informação verdadeira por uma informação oficial, de um governo, uma empresa, etc. Todos tem direito de contar a sua versão de cada fato, mas considero que, se os artigos devem ser pagos, porque não colocamos pop-ups com publicidademais explícita na Wikipédia? Assim, o dinheiro iria para os cofres da Wikipédia, e ela poderia desenvolver mais e mais projetos em prol da cultura. Acho que, com este dinheiro, a Wikipédia poderia passar a identificar os fraudadores da informação, envolvidos com o interesse dos seus contratantes ou patrões.--179.232.82.99 22:13, 10 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Thank you for expressing your concern about paid content on Wikipedia. To be clear, this amendment does not endorse paid advocacy editing. You can read more here. Thanks. Geoffbrigham (talk) 17:51, 12 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Idenfication by Wikipedia itself the fraudsters paid producers of articles[edit]

I use Wikipedia occasionally and realize its importance to culture, and she replaced the traditional encyclopedias. Thus, it seems like criminal conduct to replace real information with official information, from a government, a company, etc. Everyone has the right to tell his side of every fact, but I believe that if the articles are to be paid, why not put pop-ups with more explicit advertisements in Wikipedia? Thus, the money would go into the coffers of Wikipedia, and she could develop more and more projects on culture. I think that with this money, Wikipedia could pass the information to identify the fraudsters involved with the interests of their employers or contractors -. ~ ~ ~ ~ === Mi name's Joel, Brazil, and I d'ont know speak Inglish language. I use Wikipedia eventually and realize their importance to the culture, that it replaced the traditional encyclopedias. Thus, it seems criminal conduct replace accurate information by official information, a government, a company, etc.. Everyone has the right to tell his side of every fact, but I believe that if the items are to be paid, why not put pop-ups with explicit publicidademais in Wikipedia? So, the money would go into the coffers of Wikipedia, and she could develop more and more projects on culture. I think that with this money, Wikipedia could begin the information to identify the fraudsters. All are involved with the interests of their employers or contractors -. ~ ~ ~ ~

Thanks. To be clear this amendment does not endorse paid advocacy editing. Please go here for more information. Thanks. Geoffbrigham (talk) 17:48, 12 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Oppose[edit]

A noble idea, but aside from the fact that it is unenforceable I have two major qualms with it: firstly that the average user will never check editors' pages for COIs, and more significantly that the beauty of Wikipedia is the sheer volume of contributors; I realise that obviously biased contributors will produce obviously biased contributions but I believe that a measure such as this, which could be construed as an attempted restriction on editing, is a thoroughly misguided policy direction (also I literally slipped on a slope yesterday and it kind of hurt). 81.96.200.247 22:49, 10 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Thanks. I definitely hear your point. In a effort that at least partially addresses some of your concerns and those of some others, we may want to consider a more narrow version of the amendment. I have already proposed more restricted language above, and I believe we will post some other ideas shortly. Geoffbrigham (talk) 17:43, 12 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
i opppose because i didnt put jibbersish i am onnastasia myself

Indirect association[edit]

If I, as a retiree receiving retirement pay, make a contribution to an article or subject that I have some professional expertise in by virtue of my previous employment. Is that considered an "association" that should be stated?68.62.230.126 02:29, 11 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

I think you mean "affiliation." The answer is no. One needs to be directly paid for the edit. Thanks. Geoffbrigham (talk) 17:38, 12 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Comment[edit]

Note: this comment was received by email, and permission was granted to post it here. Philippe Beaudette, Wikimedia Foundation (talk) 17:24, 11 March 2014 (UTC)
I fully support any terms that promote or increase transparency including any relationship whatsoever to the article. Not just for paid work but for ANY relationship. E.g., if the editor of an article is the spouse of someone that works for a company referenced in the article (if this is allowed by Wikipedia), I would want to know that.

[reply]

The current amendment lists three places where someone could note the disclosure information. If this means the reader would need to check three places to find potential disclosures, then I would vote against that option. Disclosures should be obvious and easily accessible to the reader. I suspect most readers don't go looking for disclosures. They should serve as a flag to readers (indicating there are disclosures) and not be something a reader would have to search for. Someone on the talk page echoed this sentiment and mentioned a pop-up. That might work, but it also might annoy readers. Another option would be a DISCLOSURE button or tab, or a disclosure section at the end of the article.

Thanks for the comment. It is a tough balance. Asking people to always make a disclosure in an edit summary box can become quite cumbersome for some editors; that is why we provide options like the user page. The disclosure is primarily to help our community members to evaluate whether the edit reflects a neutral point of view. Although many paid edits do, many do not. It is less a tool for readers, as I see it, but I understand if people disagree with that. Thanks again for taking the time to read and give us your views. Geoffbrigham (talk) 17:35, 12 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Wikimedia Technology Support Ideas[edit]

Tag the edit and page: not just the user page[edit]

I feel the guideline has far too many uses of the word 'or'. When looking at a page or an edit, I'm unlikely to dig deep enough to discover where the paid editing was disclosed: 

  a statement on your user page,
  a statement on the talk page accompanying any paid contributions, or
  a statement in the edit summary accompanying any paid contributions.

I feel that when submitting an edit a box should pop up with a disclosure form. One might reference a pre-canned disclosure (e.g. "I work in Social Media at DoNoEvilCorp"), and that would be fine. But one should face the question of the relationship to the edit at each submit. This would also be a great place to say more about your authority to edit even if there is no conflict (e.g. "I worked for ten years as an auto mechanic at a Volkswagen shop"). Nothing here says your right to remain unattributed is affected: just that some background helps put your edit in context. [Disclosure: I do not expect to be paid for this contribution. I have contributed on and off to Wikipedia for ten or more years as a hobby.] Brycen (talk) 05:13, 11 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Hello Brycen, thanks for the suggestion. Adding a new a new disclosure form or checkbox may be possible, but it is also a more complicated commitment and would take some time to develop. There was some email discussion about a similar idea on Wikimedia-l.
Steven Walling provided an engineering perspective:
[With my WMF product manager hat on...]

This a big request with many moving parts. We should probably try to separate them out and simplify where we can. I'd recommend filing bugs for structured information about groups, profiles, the ability to join/leave groups, activity feeds per group, and more. This is something that is of general interest, and is not specific to COI-related issues at all.

Gryllida's comment was a bit abrasive but is a correct understanding of the challenge here I think, in terms of creating richer kinds of information about types of edits/editors without making a user do unnecessary extra work. Imagine if there is essentially as many group types as there are categories, for instance. It probably makes more sense to have collections of pages associated with a group, so that we can generate a feed of group activity not by making the user select a group when saving, but automatically. So for example: I'm in "Group:Beer" and I edit the article on "Pilsner", so my edits show in a feed of edits by Group:Beer members to articles in that subject.

In the long run, we should start creating structured information about topical groups, and let people access it both through a group page as well as some kind of editor profile. However, it's not going to happen in the next calendar year, so I'm not sure it's a good interim solution to the problem of how to make COI disclosures easier. AbuseFilter also is honestly probably not the right solution, even if self-tagging existed.

In my view, this means that it would be better to add this type of feature to the roadmap for a structured user profile that enabled users to track their affiliation, instead of a making an ad hoc feature focused on paid edits. But it also means that we are unlikely to be able to get this type feature within the next year or possibly longer. Would you be comfortable with requiring disclosure through the edit summary or talk page, until we can develop better features for users to identify their affiliations? Thanks, Stephen LaPorte (WMF) (talk) 00:12, 12 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Response: all that's a quite heavy solution to the problem. Much easier, and on track to the problem, is a single additional text field that goes with each edit record. It might be blank in most cases, but it would be available for a person to disclose a potential conflict of interest on a given edit in addition to the required disclosure in the user page/talk page. Thus each edit would have an edit summary plus a conflict disclosure statement. I'd also say the paid editing notice should be disclosed on the edit, the talk page AND the user profile. Not OR but rather AND. The version on the talk page could be removed after the paid editing gig is finished, but the others would remain. Brycen (talk) 00:32, 12 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Additional Response: I would also prefer to not have to dig into someone's user page to find out if they are a paid contributor. To granularize the paid contributor category in this matter would mean that anything that the user contributes would be under the guise of a 'paid contributor,' regardless of creating other personal edits that were not paid, as well as confusing the possibility that someone could be paid to make two different edits by two different employers. It is also too much hassle to keep looking at people's pages to find their status and thus to determine the credibility of the edit / information. In the end, I believe it muddies the ability to easily track the credibility of the information. Wandering Artist (talk) 06:34, 13 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

I hope that I am posting appropriately! I spent quite a bit of time and reading trying to find out where I should post my support and comments. I strongly support the admendment to require disclosure. This will always be a difficult area to deal with but the requirement to reveal a potential conflict of interest such as is proposed in amendment 1 along with the already strong effort to ensure unbiased and deceptive editing will, I believe, improve the ablitlity of the foundation to prevent "hijacking" of this valuable resource. I have not edited an article for quite a few years now (shame on me) but have instead been very impressed with the obvious effort to remain objective about very contriversial subjects. To me it seems pretty obvious when an article is essentially written by a person or persons with an organization affiliation and it appears, to me at least, that efforts are made to be clear that the article might not be fully objective. I feel that the collegial nature of the wiki foundation will benefit from this new requirement.

I feel that all of us with a strong background and many years of experience in a particular field but with a real love for truth and knowledge will not be harmed by having to reveal an financial connection related to our posts. I personally have never had anyone, much less a employer or even fellow employee make any suggestions about edits or postings that I have made regarding nuclear power. However, I don't feel that it is unreasonable to expect me to indicate that I have made my living in that field. Please continue the outstanding work that you do to make wikifoundation a premier information source! 184.155.220.237 17:17, 14 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

I find myself in strong agreement with Brycen! I also like the suggestion that once an affiliation/potential conflict is entered into the users page that it would automatically be part of any post. That should be editable however since the posting could be totally unrealated to the affiliation/potential conflict. 184.155.220.237 17:24, 14 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

What Exactly Constitutes Paid : It's Tricky[edit]

slippery[edit]

The definition of paid is a bit slippery in the proposal. If I'm paid by a company the difference between 'paid to edit wikipedia' and 'paid, but editnig wikipedia helps my job prospects' is pretty thin. I'd like to know if an employee or contractor to XYZ corporation made an edit: in some case it enhances the credibility of the contribution, in others it's a flag to check the details NPV and references even more closely. Brycen (talk) 06:09, 12 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

A clear case?: UC Berkeley to hire 'Wikipedian-in-Residence'[edit]

See http://abcnews.go.com/Technology/wireStory/uc-berkeley-hires-wikipedian-residence-22953509 Here the University will hire a professional Wikipedian Kevin Gorman to help individual researchers edit wikipedia. So exactly how are the professors's edits counted: are they paid contributions because a paid Wikipedian helped them? For this reason I favor a broader requirement of disclosure: any conflict and the chain that lead to it should be disclosed. Brycen (talk) 19:15, 19 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Other Comments[edit]

links[edit]

If writing a blog and I want to link to a Wikipedia page (for reference) without changing a single word or character on that page, is this acceptable? Intranaut (talk) 19:01, 11 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Can you please reword the question, its very hard to understand what your saying. Jacksalssome (talk) 08:44, 12 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Support Full Disclosure[edit]

I agree with the idea that if someone is paid to post on Wikipedia they should disclose that fact and who is paying them. I also agree that there are too many "or's" (options) for the disclosure as it's currently stated. If a post or edit is paid, it should be disclosed up-front. "PAID EDIT: (edit text follows)" with a link on PAID EDIT to who paid for it.

That said, the official organizations, individuals or people representing the individual should be able to edit & post without disclosure because we assume the data is from the source.

When the data is NOT from the source, the source should be named even if that source is "self". In truth, the source of the data we're reading should always be named regardless, but especially if it's a paid or opposing viewpoint/organization/individual.

The only problem I see is that a corrupt propagandist could get around this by being paid for something else and doing the post for "free". Example: XYZ oil company has a publicist they keep on retainer for social media marketing. It "doesn't include wikipedia" but the publicist "throws it in as a freebie". They could argue semantics & say they're not being "paid to post on wikipedia". "Paid to post on wikipedia" is too narrow to avoid possible biased posting & edits without disclosure. We should know who's posting and if they were compensated in any way.

So the disclosure rules need to say something regarding if the poster receives or has ever received any compensation of any kind from a related or opposing entity or cause, etc. It should require them to say who pays them in general. Clubware (talk) 22:28, 11 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

How do people feel about Wikipedia content being sold commercially?[edit]

Some of the basic responses to paid editing include the feeling that commercial entities are somehow "soiling the purity" of volunteer contributed Wikipedia content. This is a rather vague and subjective statement, and I don't think it is a valid argument against paid editing. Let's ask ourselves, why is Wikipedia released under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike license instead of the Creative Commons Attribution-Noncommercial-ShareAlike license? After all, even if a commercial entity decided to sell content they grabbed from Wikipedia, so long as they credit Wikipedia they're allowed to make a profit off our work; and if they don't credit us, they would be already running some legal risks. Just imagine the hard volunteer work being contributed to Wikipedia sold as commercial profit by some other entity. I know that doesn't seem to ethically sit right with many, but ask yourselves why contribute to a site that does not choose a noncommercial license?

This is not an argument for paid editing, per se, but it's meant to address many of the misconceptions the !voters have brought up as a reason against paid editing, that commercial entities are somehow "soiling the purity of volunteer-driven Wikipedia contributions". For the very reason that commercial entities are able to reuse our content (and presently also contribute to it), that the appeal to vague emotion such as "purity" and self-centered righteousness ought to be dismissed, or else Wikipedia should change its license entirely. TeleComNasSprVen (talk) 08:06, 12 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Transparency good. Undisclosed financial interest bad.[edit]

I've reduced this to the most simplistic issues as I see them. Any paid or otherwise compensated provider of information is biased. There may be exceptions but I cannot provide any examples of such. Undisclosed financial interests have ruined most commercial media.Neovivo (talk) 09:41, 12 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

A couple of exceptions have already popped up on this page alone as a counterargument for this change requiring paid editors to disclose. See the statement above by Michaeldsuarez for one. TeleComNasSprVen (talk) 11:58, 12 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
One example of this wide-spread problem affecting Wikipedia's credibility is the topic of extreme sports. Participants in extreme sports can suffer monetary losses in disposing of used equipment when knowledge replaces hype and potential customers shy away. Also, many extreme sports enthusiasts commercially train others in their disciplines, sell equipment and compete under sponsorship for prizes and income. I was once interested in using my actuarial knowledge to make Wikipedia better. I provided just one year of fatality data (over 100 deaths) with the requested citations on "Paragliding/Safety." These were almost immediately removed by posters from ParaglidingForum.com posing as unbiased Wikipedia editors. The citations remained on the Paragliding/Talk pages for over a year but I see now that they have been removed. I tried for a while to keep the information up but there seemed to be no recourse in the face of such censorship. While Wikipedia remains a fantastic source for non-controversial information, anything controversial should well be disregarded until this problem is dealt with.Nopara (talk) 20:11, 14 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Support[edit]

Support in the interest of transparency. There seem to be more than one issue here; "personal interest" AND "receiving consideration" and they are not always in synch and the discussions here are often unable to be clear on which is being targeted, this lack of clarity makes the wording a challenge. I think there can never be a test in a court of law so trying to find complicated legal language with no loopholes is wasteful, I favour a wording that conveys only the spirit of the pHALTS MAULroposal and has very easy to comply guidelines. Remedy when lapses are discovered could be flexible and perhaps include a simple locked edit on the transgressors user page for example. Most people don't care unless there is a controversy and then disclosures can be applied if missing and edits can be made on that basis if blatant non-POV is discovered. Idyllic press (talk) 19:46, 15 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Disclosure of 'potential conflict of interest' is a nice blanket term 'such as paid editing'. For example
I'd like to know if contributions are made by someone employed in the nuclear power industry, even if they are not paid for it. Brycen (talk) 18:26, 18 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Discussion for Optional Changes[edit]

We have posted two options of potential changes in the main page of the amendment. We appreciate your comments and feedback on these options, considering they are not mutually exclusive - both of them, either, or neither could be adopted by the Board (depending on whether they adopt the amendment as a whole). Please leave your feedback in the respective subsection for each option (if you are commenting on one in specific), or use the "General discussion" subsection if commenting on both of them. --JVargas (WMF) (talk) 22:34, 12 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

General discussion on both options[edit]

Please use this section if you want to support, oppose, or overall give comments on both options.We think that either or both of the two options could better focus the amendment on paid advocacy editing, which is a chief concern. However, we also realize they could raise other considerations. Your feedback on these options will help the Board as it considers what language to adopt.

I very strongly support a measure to alert readers to any content that may have been provided for financial compensation. I feel that the proposed terms of use/paid contributions amendment is appropriate as it stands. The option 1 limits the the disclosure obligation too much. A great deal of harm can be done to free and objective discourse by paid obfuscation of general knowledge in the service of corporate interests. I understand the rationale behind option 2, which requires disclosure of special interest without naming the specific affiliation - it is intended to protect people whose affiliations may be to repressed or oppressed groups such that disclosure could result in their being incarcerated or killed. However, since most people working for such groups are not financially compensated, I don't feel that this is as much of a risk as some would represent. I think the key here is to specifically alert readers when content has been inserted at the behest of and on the payroll of moneyed interests. The content can be included, but let the readers know its source so that we can form our own opinion of its reliability. To this end I believe that the source of the money that pays for the insertion must be published on the same page as the content appears. If readers have to comb through editors' profiles that will delay and deter access to this very important information. I hope that the final language of the amendment will require that the entity paying for the content insertion be published as a disclaimer on the page where the content appears, and may at the editor's discretion also appear on their profile or other relevant identifying pages.

In addition to supporting all of the proposals in the preceding paragraph, I'd like to suggest that a section be added at the end of every content page that identifies relevant associations of the editors of that content. This would include the required disclosures enumerated above, as well as disclosures of non-compensated associations. I see no problem with preserving the anonymity of editors themselves (in both compensated and non-compensated contributions). The power of the wiki structure is that it represents a collective consensus of our understanding of the world. History is full of examples of the limitations of that consensus, in the realm of science, in the oppression of minorities, and especially in the perpetuation of self-destructive cultural myth making. Documenting the associations behind this consensus may be as illuminating as the contents themselves.


  • The new optional changes still misses some key points:
    • Does not address the manner in which community members should challenge individuals they suspect of being paid editors.
    • If you're not going to use the term "paid advocacy editor" in the amendment itself, and define it in the amendment, then the amendment applies to any form of financial payment; this remains a major concern and does include anyone working for a GLAM or as a paid Wikipedian in residence.
      • Wikipedians in residence often edit in a way that could easily be seen as promotional for the institution at which they are resident. The fact that the WMF and the institution share at least some common goals does not negate the fact that most institutions also have a financial or reputational reason for ensuring that they have close ties to the highly-ranked WMF projects.
    • Removing the phrase that clearly states it applies to all Wikimedia projects implies that the amendment does not apply to all projects.
    • There is often a bigger conflict of interest in a student trying to get higher grades (and a greater risk of harm to the project, based on what we have already seen in various educational programs) than there is when an article subject trying to fix an error in their article.
  • Unfortunately, it also does not allay my concerns that the WMF is laying the burden of policing this amendment on the laps of front-line editors and administrators without sufficient support to make it anywhere near consistently enforceable across the projects; without ensuring that article subjects are provided with adequate, viable, consistently available channels to express concerns about article contents; and making all editors susceptible to on- and off-wiki sleuthing and harassment when another editor chooses to make a "paid editor" accusation at them. Risker (talk) 23:03, 13 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
Hello Risker, thanks for continuing to review and post feedback -- this is a good list of issues for consideration. Do you think that there is anything further we can do via an FAQ or other explanation to alleviate the concern about over-aggressive sleuthing for suspected undisclosed paid editors? I am trying to figure out if this issue is necessarily tied to a paid edit disclosure requirement. Thanks again, Stephen LaPorte (WMF) (talk) 00:06, 14 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
Yes, Slaporte (WMF), it's tied to the requirement to disclose, because a *failure* to disclose will then become a bannable offense. When it's not in the TOU, editors are judged on their edits and can just roll their eyes at such accusations if there's no problem with the edits. When it's in the TOU, the content of the edits is completely irrelevant; it's all about the (alleged) money. There's no defense against such an accusation; one can't prove a negative. And the proof of the allegation (because it's about the money, not the content) comes from sleuthing, usually external to Wikipedia, for "evidence" that the person is taking money for their edits. There is a very significant first-mover advantage for POV warriors to make such accusations against editors who do not share the same POV - even if the editor is bringing an article to neutrality.

I'm a bit concerned that, a month or more down the road since you started working on this, you've not realised that this amendment is about power, and not about content and not about neutrality and not about behaviour, and not really about money, either, given the number of loopholes that you folks keep trying to create to protect groups that have financial benefits but are "friends" of the WMF. The issue I have with it is that it's putting power in the hands of people who have historically been amongst the biggest problem users on WMF projects, the POV-pushers, and takes it away from the editors who try to resolve those issues. The latter group are going to be extremely vulnerable to accusations of paid editing. Risker (talk) 00:54, 14 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Risker - I guess another approach - which I think many would find a bit "watered-down" - would be to prohibit deception and paid editing as well as unlawful conduct. Something like this:
"You may not make a contribution in exchange for compensation and engage in sock-puppetry or meat-puppetry. Applicable law, or community and Foundation policies and guidelines, such as those addressing conflicts of interest or unfair business practices, may further limit or prohibit paid edits to a Wikimedia Project or require disclosure of affiliation and payment. For more information, please read our background note on disclosure of paid contributions."
The language would need to be better defined and word-smithed, but you get the idea. I'm not convinced this is the right approach, but would you support a provision like that? Thanks. Geoffbrigham (talk) 13:26, 14 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
Geoffbrigham, if I was to boil that down to very plain language, would this mean roughly "No socking if you're getting paid for your edits. Projects may make additional policies and/or guidelines."? If that's the gist of your proposal, I could entirely live with that. Risker (talk) 16:44, 14 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
Another possible approach - comments welcome:
Yep. That is basically it, Risker. The problem is how to define sock-puppetry and meat-puppetry. I've been playing with some words, but it ain't easy. It might roughly look like this:
"If you are accepting compensation in exchange for making contributions to Wikimedia projects, you may not engage in sock-puppetry; specifically, you may not create new accounts to avoid detection; use another person's account; use multiple accounts and present them as different users; or employ other people to use accounts to appear as unaffiliated contributors. Applicable law, or community and Foundation policies and guidelines, such as those addressing conflicts of interest or unfair business practices, may further limit or prohibit paid edits to a Wikimedia Project or require disclosure of affiliation and payment. For more information, please read our background note on disclosure of paid contributions."
I would want to see support for this in the community before going much further, but I'm willing to explore it if there is support. Geoffbrigham (talk) 19:18, 14 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
TeleComNasSprVen, I would be interested in your views of the above version (which makes a link to sock puppetry without actively requiring disclosure). Of course, everyone is invited to comment. Thanks, Geoffbrigham (talk) 11:43, 15 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
Hello Geoff, and apologies for not responding earlier. I had briefly considered the language of this revision, and my initial impressions were that I would probably support such measures, including both option 1 and option 2. Option 1 restricts the requirement solely to commercial and/or financial interests that receive benefits, since we do not want to adversely affect noncommercial interests too much, such as GLAM and organizations that would pay for a balanced, neutral article about themselves. Option 2 has my backing because it reduces the effects of outing and harassment, the two major concerns against this proposal going forward. TeleComNasSprVen (talk) 19:27, 15 March 2014 (UTC)`[reply]
Thanks TeleComNasSprVen - In the end, the Board will make the decision based on its experience and this consultation. I know they appreciate your stress testing our ideas here. Geoffbrigham (talk) 19:59, 16 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
Regarding the ban on sockpuppetry/meatpuppetry, I feel that is just as well a good revision to consider. TeleComNasSprVen (talk) 19:29, 15 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
Geoff, I oppose that as watered down as it does not make a bannable offense of what (I've argued) the FTC has already barred; there's no reason to say we don't have a problem with paid advocacy editing if it's done without sock puppets, that is, by exploiting a loophole.--Elvey (talk) 19:08, 18 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
        • I agree with the strong support for a broadly defined disclosure clause for ALL compensated work. My issue is that this is an ETHICS clause in the Terms of Use, and may be unenforceable except in the most egregious cases. I trust the editors to find a reasonable solution, but it should not be limited to specific entries, and ultimately we must rely upon the collective intelligence of the Wiki-community to identify and correct any unattributed editing. I would want to know that President Bush edited his own page, even if he were not compensated financially, he benefits from the legacy, the beauty of this media is that we only edit that which we care about, and no entity can pay everyone enough to hide the truth.
  • I (Dyveldi) support the original text. Possibly with the exeption for the change: «Change the words "To ensure compliance with" to "As part of these"», since this does not seem to change the content of the sentence.
  • The words or the content should not be changed after the users have voted. Issues concerning how to understand the words in ambiguous situations should be resolved in a FAQ section. Interpretation issues will arise whether the words are changed or not and I find the original words best suited. Ambiguous issues will always arise no matter how much time is spent trying to find the right ones. I do not find the new suggestion better or clearer than the original.
  • I agree that enforcement will be a challenge, but that is always the case with rules. The frontline will have to read both the words and the FAQ carefully. The risk of discovery that the rules are violated is low, but this is the case with at lot of rules. Most people are honest and do their best to comply with the rules of the society they are a member of, this is also the case with the users of the Wikimedia-projects. One of the rules are "good faith". We are obliged to assume that editors are acting in good faith. Implementing this rule will not suspend the requirement to be polite. This rule is however a useful tool for the frontline to ask polite questions of users if they are aware of the pait edit rule and if they have something to disclose.
  • I am aware of the fact that being obliged to disclose information about compensation in some cases will include the possible consequense that the identity of the editor is revealed or can be guessed. In my opinion the choice is clear, if you wish to edit anonymously you stay away from edits that can reveal your identity, paid or not.
  • This will not solve issues concerning conflict of interest, non-neutral editing or opinionated editing, but it will be an ethical standard. Most users will comply, the ones that do not will still be a problem, but they are a problem without rules as well.--Dyveldi (talk) 14:41, 16 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
Agree with all Dyveldi's points! --Elvey (talk) 19:05, 18 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Support both options, they alleviate my concerns with the original text (that it would have discouraged GLAM, contests and other good volunteer work for which there is some form of renumeration), and the amended text is still strong enough to prevent large-scale deceptive paid editing, which is the only realistical goal for a terms of use anyway. --Tgr (talk) 05:44, 17 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Support the original text and
Oppose both amendments. I see gaping loopholes within the amendment language that are surely not intentional. For example, if I edit the BP article and BP pays my way to conferences in the swiss alps (ski pass included) where BP is discussed, and/or provides a company car as compensation for my wikipedia edits, is that obviously compensation? Yes. Is that obviously financial compensation, per the proposed amendments? Well…, Steven? Should it be allowed? Of course not. I believe LCA, when crafting language, needs to put themselves in the mindset of someone looking to find a loophole that allows them to perform some kind of PAE without violating the letter of the policy. I think LCA hasn't done that enough. I think the board needs to do that as well. The amended text is NOT strong enough to prevent large-scale deceptive paid editing. Could better language be strong enough and calm GLAM? I think LCA could try again. --Elvey (talk) 19:05, 18 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

(Similar, more minor point: I also see issue with the commentary, "The intent is to try to exclude potential application to professors…". Surely it would be more appropriate to say, "The intent is to try to limit potential application to professors…" because a professor should not have carte blanche! --Elvey (talk) 19:05, 18 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Hello and thanks for the invitation to comment under the common Swedish Language Wikipedia contribution. Obviously these are only my personal views and don't represent the whole of Swedish Language Wikipedia, but I think the proposed amendments are a small step in the right direction. This should of course not be interpreted as my support for the proposal as a whole (I am still against then proposal). Problems such as scaring away potential contributors, and 'outings' (either rightly, wrongly, or as a threat), along with a lack of clarity and a sincere concern about the drain prosecuting and defending affected users could take on WMF's finances remain. Addressing each amendment in detail:

Option 1: Do not support. All moves to exclude persons such as professors and teachers (though these are far from the only people that could be unintentionally affected) from the proposal are welcomed. It is however hard to see how this would apply to those persons except in a narrow range of articles. If a professor writes about a project, an organisation or another professor at their university, they would still be affected. Indeed, what if they write about a piece of equipment that was critical in their latest study? This would surely be classed as a commercial product, and once again professors and teachers, amongst others, would fall foul of the proposal. It's hard to see how Option 1 betters the proposal in any significant way; and this is the reason to my lack of support.

Option 2: Support. Wikimedia Projects should never require users declare information which could be used to identify them. This should always be one of Wikimedia's ground pillars.

Common change in Option 1 and 2: Do not support. Whilst moves to alleviate concerns about which sorts of compensation require a declaration are welcomed, the new wording opens a whole new can of worms which could cause WMF more headaches than it realises (if the proposal was to be accepted). What constitutes financial compensation may be open to challenge, for example if an employee's car ceases to function and the employer gives them a new car instead of a bonus to the same value of a car, what's the difference? And if this bonus is for paid contributions to Wikimedia Projects, it could possibly be an effective way of getting around the proposal.

Unfortunately people who might receive some financial compensation from a sports club (or similar) that they're in, but who have not specifically been paid to edit Wikipedia (or any other project), still find themselves in an uncertain position even after the proposed changes. It is my firm belief that these people, as long as they're writing neutral and well sourced articles, should never be treated any differently to another other contributor. Witch hunts for people who make good contributions but may have been compensated in some way do nothing to promote Wikimedia as a friendly and welcoming environment.

In addition to the above mentioned situations, external entities which have been contracted by a Wikimedia Project to make edits (for example experiments regarding article readability) would be required to declare this. This is somewhat absurd when such projects often occur outside the main article area (Swedish: ”huvudnamnrymden”) and in controlled circumstances.

Changing compensation to financial compensation does little to alleviate concerns and make absolutely certain which persons are affected, and therefore support cannot be given.

Option 3: Mild support. If the proposed amendment would be accepted by Board of trustees, it should never be forced upon projects which don't want to have it. In the common submission from Swedish Language Wikipedia it was clearly demonstrated that there isn't unilateral support for the proposal. Forcing it on projects that don't want to have it may even lead to subversion tactics, and this would be less than optimal for any project. Full support cannot however be given as the proposal, if adopted, should be 'opt in', not 'opt out'. As the proposal appears to have been drafted in response to a problem relevant to only a small number of projects, a still better option would be for Board of trustees to give permission for disclosure requirements to be included in terms of use, and let each project decide if it wishes to A) require paid edit disclosures, and B) use the formulation as it exists in the proposal or write its own version. Dieselmotorvagnar (talk) 22:13, 20 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Not so small additional changes[edit]

I oppose changing the term "compensation" for "financial compensation". There are many types of compensations that are as much concern as money. If educational projects are at risk, and free lunches and other small benefits are to be excluded, then the term should be "significant economic or social compensation".106.68.110.3 03:00, 20 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Option No. 1: Adds "about an organization, living person, or commercial product" to describe the contributions.[edit]

Modify clause 1 to Academic Freedom with unbiased Responsibility as far as possible.

Please use this section to support, oppose, or overall give comments on Option No. 1. This option narrows what kinds of contributions these requirements would apply to. This focuses on topics that are potential subjects of advertisement and promotion, and excludes other topics of general interest. The intent is to try to exclude potential application to professors, teachers, and Wikipedians in Residence, and other individuals editing on topics of less commercial interest.

Modify I'm frustrated that there are two differences between option 1 & 2. Option 1 limits disclosure to those "about an organization, living person, or commercial product", but also require disclosure of the party that compensated you. I'm opposed to the former but in favour of the latter. So, I Oppose "about an organization, living person, or commercial product" and I Support "you must disclose the party that compensated you"

Oppose: This proposed softening of the current requirement narrows it too much, making it less likely that users will trust Wikipedia entries.

Oppose: The wording "commercial product" singles out one class of organization. Non-profit organizations whose avowed mission is the advocacy of a POV have a product: their POV. They sell it to their donors and they make millions of dollars pushing their POV. Why are employees and governors of these types of organizations excluded from disclosure if they are editing articles related to the mission of their organization. Using the word "commercial" just reinforces the already vicious community bias against commercial enterprise. The wording would be much more useful if it read: ...""about an organization, living person, or the products, services or mission of the organization commercial product" --Mike Cline (talk) 01:06, 13 March 2014 (UTC) Exactly, global warming is likely to have paid bias and would not fall under this categories, i support option 2 or a mixture of both.[reply]

  • I agree. Global warming, religious articles, etc. I oppose both options and want to keep the current wording. Professors won't be hurt by the requirement of stating on their page that they are being paid. 62.61.46.162 20:50, 18 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Modify: I agree with Mike. Often the quality of an article is judged on references, but it's still very easy for people to only use POV references or to even use references from their own organisation. The scientific approach works best on scientific articles, so perhaps instead of naming which articles need disclosure the articles that don't require disclosure should be named. If the compensation is from an internationally recognised higher learning institution on a topic taught all around the world then as long as the article makes no mention of the organisation or it's financial interests there shouldn't be an issue. If paid edits don't put "the products, services or mission of [a specific human] organization" (other than the mission of wanting open access to complete and verifiable global knowledge) above those of others then there would be little to criticise. Saying this, though, if they are employed by a University it would be easy to say so on their user profile - problem solved. On the other hand, if a PR employee improves the Wikipedia article about their company in any way they are technically being financially compensated for their efforts, but if those edits are purely factual without removing negatives or adding marketing dross then there shouldn't be any need to acknowledge it as paid. If an employee is hired to do those edits though, they should definitely disclose. Uno b4 (talk) 02:04, 13 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Modify: It needs to be clear what is meant by "commercial product". Our concern is surely whether the "product" is associated in any way with the activities of the employers of the editor. Otherwise, strongly in favour.Aliquis (talk) 12:17, 14 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Oppose: Option 1 excludes several kinds of topics which have been "subjects of advertisement and promotion" rather extensively. One example is tourism in some city or region. The place isn't a commercial product or an organization, but Tourism Boards routinely fund ad campaigns. Another example is a political issue or government policy. US health care policy, for example, has been the subject of many millions of US dollars in advertising in recent years, and while there are organizations, living persons, and commercial products associated with the subject, the subject itself is excluded by Option 1. 207.55.103.150 06:20, 13 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

  • It seems to me that, although this option describes the most typical instances in which problems would occur, it does not help us to limit it in this way. It is possible for an edit motivated by pay to mislead the community, even if it is not related to an organization, person, or product. --Tryptofish (talk) 17:48, 13 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
  • Oppose - not out of principal, but as a practical issue, this might be best handled at the project level. I think there will always be PR folks or similar coming around saying "but this is not really a paid editor situation" and these can be handled with reason by the projects, but the projects should have the leverage that enables them to say "NO". At the same time, I think many of the "borderline exception conundrums" have been manufactured by opponents of the whole concept of watching paid editors, trying to derail the whole amendment. These conundrums will likely disappear once the amendment is put into place. Smallbones (talk) 21:11, 13 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
  • Comment. I feel that this wording is very vague. Is an article about a railway line about an organization, because the railway line's operator is an organization? Is en:milk an article about a commercial product, because milk is often a commercial product? Is a country's legislative body an organization, and if not, does it still fall within the scope of the proposed wording because it consists of living persons? Is an article about a country covered, or only the parts about its politics, because it's kind of an organization, broadly construed? I think a paid editor will know insufficiently well from this wording what exactly is covered and what isn't. I don't know if there is a better wording. I'm generally supportive of making this amendment weaker, because I oppose it in the first place, but this isn't an improvement as far as clarity is concerned. darkweasel94 (talk) 23:00, 13 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
  • Oppose As noted above, the wording is in practice too vague and doesn't correspond to either the real world or the way Wikipedia articles are organized. "Roundup" is a commercial product – a trade name of Monsanto. "Glyphosate" is a short form of the name of the compound N-(phosphonomethyl)glycine. It is the main ingredient of Roundup. The English Wikipedia has one article: en:Roundup (herbicide) is a redirect to en:Glyphosate. So what is the position of someone paid to write about the chemistry and uses of the compound glyphosate in a way which will indirectly promote the commercial product Roundup? As also noted above, en:Global warming is neither an organization, a living person, nor a commercial product, so it would be ok for someone to be paid by an oil company to edit this article. An editor couldn't be paid to write about the en:Roman Catholic Church, because it's an organization, but could be paid by that church (or any other) to write about en:Catholicism. The wording just doesn't work. Peter coxhead (talk) 02:47, 14 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
  • Oppose On the basis of my recent rather intensive experience with promotional articles, a focus upon commerce and living people and organizations does not cover the field adequately. there have been quite a number of promotional edits on causes of various sorts, on non-commercial works of art, on decease persons--presumably relatives-- and almost anything conceivable. Probably a good number of them have been paid. Mike Cline's statement above seems the best explanation of the situation. I am not concerned about problems with project-related people. I'm a WIR myself, and I disclose it and use an obvious username (even though I'm not being financially compensated; I certainly would be particularly careful to do so if I were paid for it.) DGG (talk) 05:34, 14 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
  • Dagegen. Das klammert so wichtige POV-Bereiche wie Glaubenssysteme, Weltanschauungen (inkl. Klimazirkus und Energiewendeweltrettung), politisch motivierte Einflussnahme (siehe aktuell die Edit-Wars um die Krim) und nicht sofort offensichtliche Reklame für z.B. Urlaubsorte oder Inhaltsstoffe des positiv darzustellenden Gegenstandes (z.B. Arzneimittel) aus. Das ist viel zu wischi-waschi formuliert. Weissbier (talk) 05:44, 14 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
  • Oppose. I fully agree with the comments above by Peter coxhead, Smallbones and the anonymous 207.55.103.150. This wording is too narrow and would sanctify paid editing of a wide range of potentially controversial topics.--Hispalois (talk) 06:41, 14 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
  • Oppose: As before, these disclosures cannot be enforced. Any attempt to introduce such terms of use shifts the attention from the edits to the person who edits. What happens if a user is suspected to be paid? How to prove that a user receives compensation? Please do not introduce new terms or amendments of any kind which cannot be handled by the communities. --AFBorchert (talk) 09:43, 14 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
  • Strongly Support: I think it is time that people show on whose behalf they make their contributions online. The readers need to know who has paid for the presentation of knowledge and facts. --USBuehler (talk) 09:43, 14 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
  • @USBuehler that probably means you support the default version of the text, not option 1.
  • Oppose: his excludes important articles about historical events, scientific facts, or any type we cannot foresee yet which paid political or religious groups will try to influence. Examples: natural selection, global warming, war started by [insert country here]. 17:25, 14 March 2014 (UTC)
  • Zustimmung: Es sollte jeder kommerziell geprägte Beitrag (oder Änderung bestehender Beiträge) sichtbar sein

19:54, 14 March 2014 (UTC)

  • Det här gör inte något i förslaget bättre! -- Lavallen 15:46, 15 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
  • I oppose a change and support the original text. The words or the content should not be changed after the users have voted. Issues concerning how to understand the words should be explained in a FAQ section. Ambiguous issues will always arise no matter how much time is spent trying to find the right ones. I have made a more full comment in the general section of this discussion. --Dyveldi (talk) 14:44, 16 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
  • Oppose: Paid editing affects many more things than the listed subjects (most notably history). --NaBUru38 (talk) 02:43, 17 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
  • Oppose This is way too narrow. The initial version does not require disclosure of personal identity. My very best wishes (talk) 21:34, 17 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
  • Oppose The narrow terminology waters down the entire principle and implies that it is OK to be paid to edit other topics. We should have a broad, overarching prohibition on paid editing. Lets not start saying which topics it is and isn't OK to edit with a COI. Themfromspace (talk) 15:27, 24 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Option No. 2: Narrows down the extent of the disclosure, changing it from "your employer, client, and affiliation" to just "that you were compensated."[edit]

Please use this section to support, oppose, or overall give comments on Option No. 2. This option focuses on simply the fact that compensation was involved, rather than specific information about the editor's identity. The intent is to allow editors to identify and review paid edits without requiring editors to disclose specific information about their identity. Individual projects may supplement this rule, and create guidelines for additional disclosures, depending on the circumstances.

'Modify: Wikimedia may simply issue to each paid editor, a certificate at the end of each financial year (Feb-March) with the STATEMENT' - To whom it may concern' the number of editing jobs done by the editor and payments made to the editor and taxes if any deducted at source, so that the editor, if necessary pay income tax in his country without any tax law violations.


Modify: Compensation means a product, service or benefit is received, and if that benefit is to raise the understanding of the community there should be no reason to hide affiliation. I can see that there could be legitimate reasons to hide the exact identity of an employer, though. If, for example, a human rights activist group in a country with an oppressive government wanted to pay a journalist to research and write about human rights violations in that country there is a possibility that the oppressive government might take action within the country against that group. In light of such, employer/client identities should be recommended to be revealed (and indeed why wouldn't people take advantage of the little extra free marketing) but not mandatory. Uno b4 (talk) 02:21, 13 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Modify: [Commercial entities are protected enough by governments of all configurations, and profoundly manipulate communications for their benefit] Therefore, I suggest adding "Commercial entities require full disclosure of identity. Non-commercial entities must indicate that they were compensated."

  • I lean against this option, because it is less helpful in terms of identifying the ways in which other editors should evaluate the edit in question. --Tryptofish (talk) 17:51, 13 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
  • Comment: If adopted, should cover reasonable anticipation of compensation: e.g., "As part of these obligations, if you receive (or anticipate that you may subsequently receive) any type of compensation for any contribution, you must disclose that." FeatherPluma (talk) 06:29, 14 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
  • Oppose no. 2 - it's not the editor disclosing personal information on himself, it is the paymasters that are being disclosed. So if a company pays a middleman who pays an editor, the editor would disclose who the company and the middleman are, but nothing directly about himself. The Company and the middleman are the important ones to know about. They are the meatpuppeteers. Smallbones (talk) 20:46, 13 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
  • Comment: it seems to me to be relevant to indicate who compensated you, but less relevant to indicate you relation to that individual or organization. On the other hand, if you know you are dealing with a middleman, honest disclosure should include who is the principal. - Jmabel (talk) 00:34, 14 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
  • Oppose. If an article is written by an editor paid by an organization, the true intellectual author of the article is the organization. Readers and fellow editors have the right to know the name of that organization; just knowing that the editor was paid is rather useless. --Hispalois (talk) 06:47, 14 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
  • Comment. Much better than option 1, but I would add the obligation to disclose exactly in what form (amount, weight, number etc) the compensation is received and from whom (CEO, chair, CFO etc.) even if the officer offered you a job because you wrote so positive about her, him or their business. Of course you can do this by private e-mail to a special committe e.g. OTRS(?)  Klaas|Z4␟V:  09:29, 14 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
  • Oppose: Experience shows that in most cases disclosure is already practiced without any new terms of use. (See here for more than 2000 openly declared associations at de-wp that were confirmed by emails to OTRS). However, you cannot enforce any disclosure. Instead we need to focus on the edits and their merits alone. If someone discloses his or her background this is fine. But if someone introduces some bias into some article shall we assume that this user was paid for this? Again, please do not introduce any terms which cannot be handled by the communities. This option does not address this fundamental flaw of this proposal. --AFBorchert (talk) 09:58, 14 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
  • Oppose: As it is well ligitime for organisations to see information in WP about their history, products... well-written and correct, there is no reason they shouldn't let it do by paid authors/editors - as long as they openly say it and sources are - in this special case - are freely available.--Mideal (talk) 14:35, 14 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
  • Oppose: This limits the community's ability to distinguish between legitimate and malicious paid content. E.g. scientific content produced as science outreach component of a publicly funded science project may be legitimate and untainted by the political opinion of the funding agency. 17:32, 14 March 2014 (UTC)
  • Oppose: Too vague and open-ended. For lawyers, you aren’t doing a bang up job of describing what you really want (or the community wants). The question is (as you all have tried to put it): When is disclosure required? Answer that question and this becomes just a matter of mechanics of how to disclose, a detail each project can work out. The circumstances as to when disclosure is required needs extraordinary clarity to prevent abuse by community zealots. In my view there are three, if you will, elements of proof.
  1. Compensation is involved: This can be through contracts, fees, employment (including paid board members), grants or other explicit remuneration. (FAQs could clearly spelled what and what is not considered compensation)
  2. An organizational relationship to the compensation exists: An organization (broadly construed, to include every type of organization from individuals to nation-states to international organizations) is providing the compensation. (FAQs need to broadly construe the definition of organization).
  3. Contributions are related to the mission, purpose, products, services or identity of the organization. (FAQs can clearly clear characterize the degree to which a relationship exists or does not exist)
  • For disclosure to be required, there needs to be a clear nexus between—compensation, organization and contributions. If that nexus exists, then disclosure is required by the TOU. If that nexus does not exist, then disclosure is not required. By taking an "elements of proof" approach, no paid editing that is deemed harmful to the reputation of Wikimedia will be excluded from disclosure.--Mike Cline (talk) 11:47, 16 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
  • Det här gör inte något i förslaget bättre! -- Lavallen 15:46, 15 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Requiring a specific employer to be named is quite easy to get around for large entities. If you're worried that someone who actually works for Monsanto is going around editing GMO articles, all they need to do is hire a contractor who hires a subcontractor with a name that seems inoffensive. Someone could be hired by "Cheap Food for the Poor" to encourage more GMOs. It becomes another form of marketing.

Similarly, anyone who received a grant to study climate change should probably disclose that if they are going around advocating on behalf of climate change legislation. Would they name the grant? The institution they work for? What if they are hired to work in the field, and on their own time, go in and edit articles in a way that may benefit their future employment?

In the U.S. there is a fair amount of focus being brought on any kind of donor to smear them publicly. Perhaps this rule change is intended to find ways to go after the Koch brothers, which seems to be trendy. In other countries, people are fired or arrested for disagreeing with the people in power. The policy requiring naming of employers might put those employers in harms way - picture someone from Amnesty International making corrections to a page that makes it more accurate; but disclosing that also makes it easier to target them. How many journalists have died in Russia in the last 20 years?

Honestly, I don't believe that just because someone is "compensated" it means it is more or less accurate. I suspect there are lots of regular employees who correct and balance their employer's pages rather than let biased complaints go unanswered. Not every company has someone paid to address things. I think we want to encourage people to engage in the community. I'm thinking now of a tire company that leaves bad reviews on their own web page, but adds a comment with the customer service phone number and invites the unhappy person to contact them. I suspect that there are many, many advocates who make their living in the advocacy field, but who may not feel compelled to disclose that if they aren't specifically compensated to change wikipedia entries. They're paid for advocacy, and do the wikipedia stuff for free. So they don't disclose. This will likely happen across the spectrum.

Honestly, mostly I think you'll get PR people willing to disclose, so a company can hire some copy editors who are technically proficient and can go correct entries without them hiring a full-time person. Just hire a firm to check every once in a while. In other words, the boring, noncontroversial pages will be the ones who are happy to disclose. (unsigned contribution)

  • I oppose a change and support the original text. The words or the content should not be changed after the users have voted. Issues concerning how to understand the words should be explained in a FAQ section. Ambiguous issues will always arise no matter how much time is spent trying to find the right ones. I have made a more full comment in the general section of this discussion. --Dyveldi (talk) 14:45, 16 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
  • Oppose - It's important to know the employer and client, it helps to understand the contexto. It's not like they are disclosing their address and credit card, by the way. --NaBUru38 (talk) 02:49, 17 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
  • Oppose - This option clearly precludes the transparency goals of the amendment. Niffweed17 (talk) 14:55, 17 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
  • Oppose. Per above. My very best wishes (talk) 21:36, 17 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
  • Support, But... This is the only version of the language I would support at all. Edits should be judged on their own merits as much as possible. I like that this has as few details as possible, because I don't think this proposal makes much sense, and therefore would like to see as narrow a version as practicable take effect. I only support this option with the realization that the proposal will probably take effect in some form. 72.35.149.153 05:08, 18 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
  • Oppose Again, this waters down the proposal. We need to strengthen these guidelines, not weaken them. This wording will help get out just who exactly is pulling the strings behind paid editors. This will greatly help our integrity and show the world that we mean business about being an unbiased source of knowledge. Themfromspace (talk) 15:30, 24 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Option No. 3: Allowing projects to write an alternative disclosure policy[edit]

One modification (suggested by Martinp and others) is to allow local projects to craft an alternative disclosure policy. The idea is that local projects can pass an alternative disclosure policy, similar to an EDP under the licensing policy for fair use. This would be possible by adding the following paragraph to the current proposal:

A Wikimedia Project community may adopt an alternative paid contribution disclosure policy. If a Project adopts an alternative disclosure policy, you may comply with that policy instead of the requirements in this section when contributing to that Project. An alternative paid contribution policy will only supersede these requirements if it is approved by the relevant Project community and listed in the alternative disclosure policy page [to be created].

Is there other support for adding this (or a similar option) to the proposal? Thanks, Stephen LaPorte (WMF) (talk) 01:07, 19 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

If the proposed amendment comes as bad as it is, it would be a relief to have at least an opt-out option for individual projects. However, you write alternative disclosure policy and a modification requires approval of the WMF. This sounds as if a simple opt-out cannot be implemented for a project. --AFBorchert (talk) 16:33, 19 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
Thanks AFBorchert. If we were to include this option, the goal would be to keep it as simple as possible where a project has consensus on a better alternative. The WMF's approval would provide an opportunity to weigh in on the legal enforceability of an alternative disclosure policy, if a project wished for it to be legally enforceable. Would you prefer "...and reviewed with the Wikimedia Foundation", or to remove this part entirely? I am curious if there is support for this option in some form. Best, Stephen LaPorte (WMF) (talk) 18:43, 19 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
Hello AFBorchert, I adjusted the language above to require that disclosure policies are listed on a central page. Thanks, Stephen LaPorte (WMF) (talk) 21:32, 19 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
Thanks for the adjustment, Stephen LaPorte! This looks good to me now. I do not know how much support this is likely to receive but I think that an opt-out should be an option for a project if the project community approves it. Regards, AFBorchert (talk) 06:14, 20 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Oppose Option 3 - It seems vague and abusable. Wiki needs a conguent policy we can trust. - E. Rowe, BSPharm

  • Oppose The WMF has its heart in the right place with this guideline and I'm worried that individual wikis, including the English Wikipedia, could develop a small local consensus (without the valuable input of all the disassociated users that we have here) to undermine these guidelines. For example, there are many people on en.wiki who believe that disclosing paid editing is akin to "outing" and harrassment. Many would rather bury paid editing and protect the paid editors "privacy rights" than worry about the issues that come with paid COI editing. The issue of paid COI editing is strong enough and dangerous enough to our integrity for the WMF to step in and enforce a blanket guideline that individual projects cannot override. Individual projects should be able to strengthen this guideline but in no way should they be able to weaken it. Themfromspace (talk) 15:48, 24 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

strong oppose[edit]

  1. oppose de midkera comqew com cinmksa. Terinma ca djkinka ma. Berintonsa ca fomsexito can. Wikipedia sonmon den cosidko homocideonat sdjik.

Translation in English: Privacy concerns. People could be outed and injured or killed. Also fails to disclose conflicts of interests of volunteers, such as supporters of a political party. Wikipedia should not be an accessory to murder if people are outed. Stephanie Bowman (talk) 04:24, 13 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Accessory to murder? KonveyorBelt 16:05, 13 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
In my opinion you shouldn't edit Wikipedia in the first place to prevent such thing to happen.--AldNonUcallin?☎ 22:54, 13 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Being able to see clearly whats going on with a page's politics in the history[edit]

It would be good to see when a notable person has been making excessive edits to a page. If you could see at a glance in the history what position the contribution was coming from, i.e. whether a contribution is for example from the owner of that company, or is an actor in question themselves etc. It could, if done well, make it clear what sort of discussion has been taking place on the subject simply by looking at the title of involved participants.Formed4 (talk) 16:07, 13 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Agree: an overview who change how much and maybe one that shows a timeline of changes (like a stock exchange order volume) would be great! (Sometimes you find something to be change and wonder about the main author/editor, that hasn't to be the one with the most edits of the last version page.)--Mideal (talk) 14:31, 14 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Marketing Magazine (Marketingmag.ca) piece[edit]

Wikipedia may lift ban on PR people editing entries
Founder Jimmy Wales once said Wikipedia was no place for the “puffery and spin” of PR. That could change.
by Marketing magazine, reprinted at http://www.macleans.ca/economy/business/wikipedia-to-the-pr-industry-maybe-youre-not-so-bad-after-all/

Wow. This is exactly what we don't want - our attempt to bring the WikiPR abuses under control being misconstrued by marketers as a weakening of existing policies. Perhaps the policy needs to explicitly prohibit WP:COI editing unless an individual, local project explicitly endorses a weaker "edit, but disclose" position? K7L (talk) 19:04, 13 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

But the wikimedia do wonna know the names of the companies who are willing to pay for contributions? So, the door for advertising is not fully closed anymore? Pieter2 (talk) 22:48, 13 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
The piece is horribly off-point. In fact it seems to have been written from a single source, a PR-spinster. There is essentially no information on anything going on here in that article. Smallbones (talk) 16:00, 14 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Disclosing one’s affiliation on Wikipedia "in the proper way"[edit]

The FAQ includes the following passage:

"National legislation of EU member states may further restrict undisclosed paid contributions, such as through local competition laws, and, for similar reasons, local national courts may find violations in failing to disclose one’s affiliation on Wikipedia in the proper way."
