It should be noted that Wikipedia currently does not enable contributors to disclose their affiliation "in the proper way". The German court made clear that talk page disclosure or disclosure on an editor's user page was not sufficient; the only "proper way" to disclose would be to do so on the article page itself, where the reader sees it.

The fact that "proper" disclosure may be impossible is material, and FAQ readers should be made aware of the fact that talk page or user page disclosure is not enough to safeguard them against legal liability. I therefore suggest the following amendment:

"National legislation of EU member states may further restrict undisclosed paid contributions, such as through local competition laws, and, for similar reasons, local national courts may find violations in any paid contribution to Wikipedia whose provenance is not clearly apparent to the reader of the resulting Wikipedia article." Andreas JN466 01:53, 14 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Makes sense to me Andreas. I will make that change. Geoffbrigham (talk) 13:04, 14 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
This is the sentence I added: "Indeed, government authorities may require disclosures of paid editing that are impossible to execute on Wikipedia - such as disclosures by businesses in the article itself to ensure notice to the reader; in such cases, paid editing is not allowed on the Wikimedia sites." Geoffbrigham (talk) 13:13, 14 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
Thanks, Geoff. Andreas JN466 07:03, 15 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
I couldn't believe it when i read the amendment, i was like "say what? on the user page??? on the talk page??? who will ever look there when she reads an article???" There should definitely be some tagging required, similar to "citation needed" or the likes, next to each and every sentence/paragraph that is paid for.--Gyll (talk) 13:24, 14 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]


STRONGLY SUPPORT GYLL ABOVE... proposal does not go far enough.
I agree that disclosing payment/affiliation on one's user page is NOT enough to inform the reader of the potential bias in an article. Most readers probably don't even know what a user page is--I know my friends don't. Disclosure has to be made on a talk page.
In addition, I agree we need to flag paid editing on the article itself, preferably to identify all contributions that were paid for. If you just note the article includes paid edits, a reader will not know what is probable PR.
In other words, if you open Pandora's box to commercial interests, you have to identify all the monsters that flew out of it.
One final note: people, even experts reading material in their own field, often miss bias because human beings rely on certain cognitive heuristics in processing information, and this leads to error because people assume they have adequately compensated for bias. (For details see the research of Nobel laureate Daniel Kahneman.) If we think we are clever enough to spot all spin, including the details that are artfully left out, or minimized, we are fooling ourselves.16:51, 16 March 2014 (UTC)Saenger

Möglichkeit 2[edit]

Hi,

es sollten alle (!) kommerziell geprägten Artikel / Änderungen erkennbar sein.

80 dd (talk) 19:47, 14 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Hola, soy de Uruguay y mi principal preoccupación es de donde van a sacar el dinero para pagar a los miles de editores de Wikipedia?

¿Mediante clics por google? ¡¿O por medio de publicidad??

thanks

Hi. Most editors are only volunteers. We pay for our infrastructure through donations. The Wikimedia Foundation, which runs the sites for the community, is a non-profit organization. Geoffbrigham (talk) 05:06, 15 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
Este cambio no significa que la Wikimedia Foundation va a pagar a los editores voluntarios. Pero si un editor es pagado por una compañía comercial, habrá que declararlo. Andreas JN466 07:14, 15 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Möglichkeit 3[edit]

Ist ja wohl der Witz des Jahres.

Dit funktioniert doch eh nicht. Das Internet lügt!


To permit this would immediately place the veracity of content in the same calibre as "Snopes", "Politics", and/or "Religion" truth at inception, now all propaganda, under the premise of goodwill and truth. As with the three aforementioned, people will still look towards you with trusting faith, but will become fools for doing so. 174.48.243.225 08:43, 15 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Wikipedia in the center of the universe[edit]

In the time of Galileo Galilei the world was mostly designed by the church. They said what the world has to believe. The people who said something else were against the church and against god. This was for a very long time like that. Nowadays the variety of life, of thinking, of feeling, of habits, of clouthing, of identity ... did change a lot until then. Until the rise of internet, the world could explore the world in a very strong new way. In a global time without real rules, the companies and other organizations can do very lot things in the space between the different national rules n law. There are no global rules. And there is nobody, that protect this "open space". No real law brings a big potential, potential for new ideas. The potential of good and the potential of bad. We know all the NGO's nowadays. The reality is, that a lot of NGO's are not anymore neutral or working in the origin sense of their founding time. They are working for money or working for some specific interestes. The "conflict of interestes" in space without real law and rules brings back the very old system of "First come, first served". Or more modern the egoism. Without the beliving of working all together, the "system" let the most fast thinking and most powerful participant win. In a system, where everybody hide his privacy or have different idendities and different playing roles, you can not only your husband or wife descover every day new, also yourself. So no a lot things are realy clear. The factor entertainment is f.e.g. more important or powerful than the factor virtues. Everything is allowed, as long nobody complains. The church or nowadays the big power of today fear the democratic potential of internet. They act different than the church in the middle age, but in the same meaning. Wikipedia is already a big power for and in the world nowadays. Long ago rich n powerful people remarked the potential of this site. As the NSA was working with google, yahoo, facebook and and and.. wikipedia couldnt hold the neutral position. When you can get million of million dollars, what would you say? The administrators of wp were in the beginning perhaps neutral. The communication were in the beginning democratic. The technics was in the beginning neutral and equal for all. It was neutral. It was a project of idealistic people. It was trustful. It was a constructive discourse. Now its a money-machine. A global money-machine. And with that it can not be neutral nor help the people. It will help the money and the system of egoism. Is there a project to protect the whistleblowers? Is there a project to think at the origins and to obtained the origin idea and philosophy? Or will it soon be a "multinational corporation" a "holding", an unimaginable extreme huge institution. Google is leading the digital world and does not bring good global rules to the world, what would need brave actions. This is perhaps the moderns stile of the roman imperium. WP will help the people, but only a few people. A little group will become more rich and more powerful but the main people will become more poor and dependent. The system of machines, the thinking of machines was and is against the variety of life.

The factor entertainment is more important or powerful than the factor virtues in the daily contact between people. Everything is allowed, as long nobody complains. Complaining is as uncomfortable as a having no fridge in nowadays world. As long as human believe to help others with technical instruments only they understand, the wall between themselves has to grow. For a constructive system WP has to become much more transparent and easy understandable. Probably in an anonymous society as our nowedays not realy possible. As long as we believe to know somebody we did not see personaly every week for houres for at least 2 years, we deceive ourselves and the world. An illusion becomes reality as in the time of Galilei. --93.184.26.78 14:06, 15 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Compensation and "Vested Interest" are often interwoven.[edit]

I perceived an instant contradiction between some of the draft wording here (many of which used the phrase "financial compensation) while at the same time, under Definitions, "compensation" is defined thus - "What do you mean by “compensation”? "As used in this provision, 'compensation' means an exchange of money, goods, or services."

As I read that definition, "financial" compensation is only one of three identified means of compensation. This ambiguity seems to be addressed or skirted multiple times here as persons seek to enlarge or clarify the terms of compensation. Looking at it head-on I wonder how vested interest (in content presentation) fits into the discussion... as it undoubtedly confers gravitas, ascendency and influence in many topics of ie. international relations, spirituality/religion, politics, "morals," and certainly "history."

Do American Indians knowing about a particular historic battle (vividly remembered through the stories of elders) have some kind of rebuttal-force against academic dominant-culture historians still "mis-remembering" the event and promulgating some semi-plausible rationale (offered by the white soldiers) FOR the massacre? What if the dominant-culture historian... by editing the Wikipedia article... enhances his or her own academic standing by reinforcing the dominant paradigm and his/her own "academic" editorial reputation?

When there is active political or cultural dissent in a country, who gets to write the story of the dissent event? If a nationalistically-identified editor portrays the event as motivated by "anarchists" and "hooligans" (and receives pats on the back from the nationalist party leaders for it) is that compensation? When dissident members in the anti-nationalistic movement edit the article to more sympathetically (perhaps accurately) depict their grievances... as participants are they "compensated" by having the nationalist version "lose" ground and popular opinion tilt more in their direction within the spectrum?

Where does the maxim "Whomever triumphs in history gets to write the history" apply here? Does not having "won" a skirmish or an intellectual/moral "war" become the opportunity to define history (as when an editor belongs to the dominating faction gaining consequential and inherent privilege... after triumphing within a political doctrinal shift, the redefinition of a complex conceptual/functional structure like the World Wide Web, shaping an international religion such as Catholicism or Tibetan Buddhism, espousing a moral-movement such as the anti-reformists hoping to rob GLBTs of marital and other benefits-equality or, bolstering the ruling class in a authoritarian country's civil war. Is not such an editor "compensated" by privilege if his or her view prevails? He/she AND all their like-minded friends (sharing ideology or suppressing a dissenting view) mutually benefit when the "loser's cause" is written-out of history, do they not?

In Wikipedia biographies of controversial figures ie. L. Ron Hubbard, Geshe Michael Roche, Pope Benedict and Chögyam Trungpa Rinpoche can become heated cross-editing exchanges. The prevailing editor "wins" if his or her either most-loved person or most-hated person, respectively, is (as a consequence of their editing) either more admired or more reviled. Are not such editors' positions-in-life notably enhanced when their highly-invested views prevail? (Even if they have written in an entirely reasonable, non-inflammatory way... helpfully "defining the territory" so to speak, for the "sake of" those less knowledgeable about the "real story.")

I believe these examples make enough of my point. Often compensations are tangible (stipends, fees, bursaries, salaries, executive privileges, exclusive memberships, commissions) and almost as often they are intangible - the relational perks, the power to control opinion, the rise in the public's esteem of one's acumen and advocacy, the likelihood of academic or political favours because of one's espousing "the cause," and all the social and cultural advantages which come with elevating one's own (and one's class/cohort's) views and suppressing another's. This is certainly as true in intellectual and academic writing as it is in political, religious and "moral" writing.

How can one possibly get an editor to reveal these other affiliations, takings-of-side and dominant-culture attitudes in exchange (often) for a bit of fame, control of the "truth," and enhanced social esteem amongst those sharing one's own perspective of the situation, the history, the controversy or the struggle?

Being compelled to reveal "I have a vested interest in this topic" would be, in my view, fantastic. "I ask if I should recuse myself from this topic because I and/or my social cohort would personally benefit from the outcome" is another way to go. Honorable and ethical codes of conduct can always be encouraged (because they can't be easily enforced in this environment). But in the last analysis, writing oneself into the "winning side" of an argument is perhaps the most powerful editorial compensation which exists. Michaelbix (talk) 04:45, 17 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Good points! Summary:
tl;dr: There are financial COIs even in the absence of "financial compensation", that should require disclosure.
I propose some language derived from here. Namely, language that addresses:

Some more "How will this provision affect" questions[edit]

How will this provision affect employees that edit articles related to their employ, specifically:

  1. An acupuncturist editing en:placebo? en:Homeopathy? (Editing content about competitors)
  2. en:BBB staff editing en:Class Action? (There's a FCOI that introduces bias, but there's no direct financial compensation for the editing.)
  3. en:Americans_for_a_Better_Tomorrow,_Tomorrow staff editing en:Publicly funded elections? en:Americans_for_a_Better_Tomorrow,_Tomorrow itself? (lobbyist / SuperPAC)
  4. a wireless carrier employee editing en:SAR score? (Editing content that discusses employer's product safety)
  5. each of the above where the employee pays someone to do the editing instead of doing it directly.

The FAQ entry for What do you mean by “compensation”? is short! Does it leave loopholes? It reads:

As used in this provision, “compensation” means an exchange of money, goods, or services.

Any objections to swapping in something better to replace "exchange for a particular contribution" in the FAQ? Requested advocacy does not become OK just because a particular edit to effect that advocacy isn't specified. I'm considering being bold. "exchange for guided contribution" or ""exchange for implicitly or explicitly requested contributions" or "for advantageous editing" --Elvey (talk) 01:44, 19 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

98.231.84.118 06:30, 17 March 2014 (UTC)World Book Like? And occasional fund drives like Public Television[edit]

I'm just a user, not a scholar.

Just suggesting it be run similar to the way encyclopedia's used to be organized. Since I'm on the high side of middle aged, I still love my World Books from 1967 with yrly books after. 2 HUGE dictionaries also and a 'Cyclo Teacher'. Look that one up. *G* A teaching tool. Still have it. Perhaps teaching items could be sold to help support staff salaries?? Fund raising would be a decent part. If sold large scale, price might stay decent since it would be for non-profit, it should stay a bit cheaper, therefore selling a LOT probably worldwise.

Staff could verify with experts, etc, that kind of people constantly. 'Documentation' in the computer field (of procedures, knowledge, etc) is in a loose way similar to what you provide. It has to be written and verified by in house computer experts.

As I see what is proposed, how exactly would you verify the info given????? How would the 'paid' person's (out of the woodwork, expert, person with 'an agenda', etc) input be given credibility? If a Wpedia staff is verifying, there is no allegiance to anyone except Wpedia and their boss.

Public Television fund raisers explain themselves, grants accepted eagerly. Teaching items need not be specific Wpedia info, but actual learning aids for various peoples of ALL sorts. TONS of products available from World Book, but all USEFUL I believe. Guess it could be most anything if you made it useful OR 'want'able (advertising campaign), like M&M cutsy or whatever (more serious).

My 2 cents, Joyce 98.231.84.118 06:30, 17 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Thanks Joyce for your comment. Geoffbrigham (talk) 08:30, 17 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Wikipedia team to help companies[edit]

I remember reading an interesting article some two years ago: Companies struggle to correct faulty Wikipedia entries, April 18, 2012, TG Daily

The real issue is not about companies trying to pay for cosmetic articles. The real problem is they don't know how to maintain the Wikipedia articles about them and there are no specialists to do such a job.

Most of the companies don't know how to add information or to maintain (the accuracy of) the Wikipedia article about their company. It doesn't make sense to have an employee in the company just to keep the Wikipedia page accurate - 99% of the time they will have nothing to do. Their IT staff are too busy to do their job, they can't become versed into Wikipedia as it needs practice, and there is not much to practice in a single article - you can't become versed by practicing two hours each three months. Their marketing teams are in a different mind setup than the mind setup needed for editing an encyclopedia - they are looking for doing something sensational, that attracts attention. If the company will try to outsource the job to some professionals, those people will do what they know - adding marketing info (The PRSA says it's also discovered that PR people barely understand Wikipedia's rules for editing - in the TG Daily article). The companies need to hire some encyclopedic (economic) professionals, not marketing professionals.

I think Wikipedia should create a team of 5-10 people good at economy from an encyclopedic point of view: history of economy, overview of economy and social impact of economy. This team should work together with companies, asking the companies to help provide information that is important from a historic and encyclopedic perspective. Of course, the company might try to supply only the positive information and not the negative information about the company. However, that's much better than nothing. Also, maybe they can provide "negative" information (or at least hints) about their competitors?

I really believe such a team is needed. It can start as an experiment, for say one year. They will experiment the concept working with a set of companies - big and small - that can help to get experienced into this kind of work and to learn as much as possible. In time, the team can offer such services for money, and they will offer a needed service that no one else is capable to offer. For starting, there are all kind of development funds offered by governments, like en:Structural Funds and Cohesion Fund, there should be funds for cultural activities too. This is nothing about sucking govt. funds for profit. It's just about maintaining accurate information about the country's economy and about offering a service that is needed and no one else can do it better.

I also think that Wikipedia should work closely with the governments in order to document certain significantly cultural things (like museums and monuments) and to maintain (and display) plain statistics (like the history of corn production in USA) in a form that's user-friendly. It's in the interest of the government to take care of knowledge and transparency. Such Wikipedia teams to interface with governments should exist. Nobody can do paid editing better than teams of encyclopedic people working for Wikipedia.

Look what en:Sir Tim Berners-Lee said in 2012: These developments are encouraging, but the simple message to governments around the world must be consistent and forceful: raw data, now! Opening up data is fundamentally about more efficient use of resources and improving service delivery for citizens. The effects of that are far reaching: innovation, transparency, accountability, better governance and economic growth.

Almost all the raw data covered by national institutes of statistics should be presented in a friendly form that is easy to find and to compile by the citizens. I can't see a better place to host such data than on Wikipedia. Therefore the government should hire Wikipedia to do the job

Yes, I am very much for paid eding. Wikipedia teams (people hired and under direct control of WikiMedia Foundation, not groups started by any Wikipedia editors) should be paid for documenting cultural and economic issues and for introducing plain, dry statistics. I don't want to become part of such teams, because it would reduce the freedom that I have now - I edit Wikipedia only when I enjoy it. But such teams are needed. —  Ark25  (talk) 08:26, 17 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Avis d’un utilisateur[edit]

Non au "Paid contributions amendment".

C’est la porte ouverte à tous les abus ! Un utilisateur.

Pour être clair, cette modification ne nécessite que la divulgation d'une édition payé - il n'approuve pas l'édition payée. Merci. Geoffbrigham (talk) 13:28, 17 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Seems fair.[edit]

Whether we like it or not, knowledge is valuable and being a huge, free database of knowledge Wikipedia is attractive to companies and institutions because it costs them nothing to be represented and therefore advertised. Just by adding sources, the site is linking out to other, frequently paying, sites.

Declared or not, personal around the world will still have it in their job description to ensure that the pages reflecting their work (in particular specialist fields) up to date and relevant. The real problem is with the medical pages. Here information is readily available for almost every disease known to man and like it or not this information affects treatments in a clinical environment. This very information is used by patients all over the world to educated themselves and their loved ones, and has frequently been noticed as a source of information for students of medicine and the biosciences. Even doctors round the world have reported using wiki to look up rarer diseases instead of going through the original research journals or medical textbooks (which may be out of date). Wikipedia may provide medical information in a more timely manner than going through medical journals and text books.12.163.39.66 10:33, 19 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

This is an area that needs rigorous editing and overview by compensated, competent, accredited professionals. This is a matter of global health. I suggest compensated editing and evaluation of critical pages, that are declared and open to public scrutiny, naturally fully referenced from the literature.

78.248.87.154 16:10, 17 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Don't fully understand all the logistics I'm sure, but I AGREE after reading the various talk on this page. PLEASE SEE MY LINK ON WHY I THINK WIKI NEEDS MORE TRANSPARENCY![edit]

http://www.thehealthyhomeeconomist.com/coconut-oil-blackballed-by-wikipedia/

Please choose wisely, WIKI is a great source of information turning humanity GOOD.

QUOTE " ... In practice, many subject areas of the project can be easily highjacked by a small group of paid editors coordinated from a single center, and I edited in one of such subject areas. Not any more. 24.11.55.66 16:42, 9 March 2014 (UTC) "

Reading more thoroughly now it seems like this is going in the right direction, but I just wanted to say, the current Coconut article is quite like if the earth page said it was flat! maybe we could atleast get another topic that says 'alchemist or magical standpoint'!, lol.

Sehr gut! Ich unterstütze die Vorschläge aus folgenden Gründen: Der Grundgedanke ist und sollte bleiben das JEDER an Wikipedia mitarbeiten kann. Neben den oft beschriebenen Lobbyisten gibt es aber auch einige die einfach nur Geld verdienen wollen und aus diesem Grund (nach meiner Beobachtung) häufig unqualifizierte Links einstellen. Nach meiner Erfahrung haben sehr viele Wikipedia Nutzer keine ausreichende Medienkompetenz, damit will ich sagen dass alleine die Offenlegung der Einnahmen sicher nicht ausreicht dem Durchschnittsnutzer die Bewertung für sich selbst richtig duchzuführen. Vorschlag: Ähnlich wie es für die Lebensmittel eine „Ampel“ geben sollte (gibt) haltet ich es für sinnvoll eine deutlich sichtbare Ampel zu zeigen (Grün/Gelb/Rot) die den Nutzer motiviert doch mal in die Diskussionsseite zu schauen und sich selbst ein Bild zu machen. --PeterKaiser (talk) 10:09, 19 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

In addition to the lobbyists often described but there are also some who just want to make money and this is why (in my observation) set often unqualified links. I 've had this been tried on the affected pages to discuss this but find quickly that these people better master the wiki mechanisms like me and gave up.
Yes I even went as far as each author / editor must briefly disclose his intention. What I submit . In my experience, a lot of Wikipedia users have no adequate media literacy , so I want to say that alone disclosing the revenue certainly not sufficient for the average user for yourself perform with due assessment properly. Suggestion: Like there should be for the food a " traffic light " ( is ) I think it would be useful in a clearly visible lights show ( green / yellow / red) that the user motivated it out to look at the talk page and get yourself a to make image . - Peter Kaiser ( talk) 10:09 , 19 March 2014 ( UTC)

What will we do after approval?[edit]

  • Hello all. Greeting from Turkey. I have a question about this amendment.

What will we do after Board of Trustees' approval of this amendment? Will we create a policy about it or something different? What are you planning about this? Can you give me information? Thanks. --ravages 10:24, 19 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

I expect the Board to review all the arguments and decide what version it prefers (if any). Most of the versions however only require approval by the Board without further need for additional policies. I hope that helps. Geoffbrigham (talk) 12:29, 19 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Additional comments[edit]

Matter is an illusion. You are free entities.

This is the end. We had a good run. I say "we", but of course I had no actual part in it. I simply consumed, as consumers are want to do. Still, I felt an odd sense of liberation when I pondered on the implications of a truly free source of information. Considering a future where the population was informed and intelligent; thus rendering some sense of validity in this faux-democracy, where votes are collected by deceiving and manipulating the populace.

Now, of course, we have people paying to anonymously "contribute" (see: "change") this on-going record of human knowledge. In other words, Wikipedia has been added to the list of mainstream media which can be changed to suit the whims of the elite. It has been a long time coming, and I thank the honest contributors who attempted to expand the knowledge of the population for the sake of doing so; as opposed to the obvious political or economical reasons which will now become commonplace; whilst they had the chance to do so.

I look forward to the next glimmer of hope which would supposedly lead toward an actual enlightened utopia; until that too is stamped out and used as an additional tool of mass manipulation. —The preceding unsigned comment was added by 61.164.89.30 (talk • contribs) .}

No to Option 2. If I'm reading correctly, Option 1 language opens editing so that persons paid by organizations can edit "ideas", scientific fact (as we know it) and the like. I would suggest the rules are not changed to allow a religious organization rewrite the "Evolution" article without disclosure of compensation (but do they really need compensation to do so? Probably not...). No change. I donate. Protect wikipedia. 71.63.244.164 13:10, 17 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

If people are being paid to post, I want the option of knowing they may have other motives for the post. I don't think option one would help much when its really needed someone will always find a way round rules. But opt 2 is a great simple i decide myself :)

  • wikimedia.org needs to return to, & maintain it's basic, clean & valued information resource, with all other assets defined as 'ßresources'.
  • wikimedia.org is 'clearly' entitled whatever funding, & other resources that can be secured to 'clearly' add value to the pool of defined-information.
  • wikimedia.org should consider adding a 1 thru 10 'consensus-value' to each published 'Wikipedia-Page' summating the +&- vote from each member.
  • The …'undisclosed paid editing' is a problem, with the …'undisclosed paid'… part a deal-killer' for anything to qualify for "Amendment" status.
  • You can simplify the entire "Terms of Use" issue & secure funding from all sources by creating, or including them in a defined category, i.e."Wikidata"
  • New funding sources should 'clearly' defining the objectives, measure the value & track the performance of any new category of information.
  • …
  • …
  • …keep up the good work…good luck!

Why three different ways?[edit]

I am disappointed to see that the proposed wording changes don't address the simplest issue: we're making it so that those interested in checking if an article is paid have to go through an absurdly convoluted procedure to do so. Check the history of the article, check the history of the userpage, check the history/archives of the talkpage, and no standard format for any of these things.

For this policy to really work, so that people can do site-level statistics on the paid editors, flag any article with paid contributions, etc., you have to settle on ONE way for these to be indicated. What's more, that one way should be somewhere distinctive, easily found, easily webcrawled -- for example, a special subpage or a specific mechanism. For example, it should be possible for someone to run a script that flags all reverts (other than self-) by paid editors so that volunteers can review them. It should also be possible to search through these edits for keywords like, say, "leading", "number one", "forefront", "ground-breaking"... well, you get the picture. Wnt (talk) 20:27, 20 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Hello Wnt, the intent of allowing three types of disclosure is to make this a minimal requirement in the Terms of Use. I see the benefit of requiring one specific type of disclosure (especially if it is machine readable, etc. as you suggest) for Wikipedia. Projects may set a stricter requirement for disclosure, and this Terms of Use proposal would require users to follow that more specific requirement as well. Thanks for your feedback. Stephen LaPorte (WMF) (talk) 22:58, 20 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Tired of the legal policies, among others // Fatigué des politiques juridiques, entre autres[edit]

English

I begin to be tired of the modification (thinking, translating, commenting, advertising the community, rethinking, retranslating, dealing with blocker points, etc.) of the legal policies, among others. Since one year were changed: the privacy policy, the term of use policy, the trademark policy, the data retention policy, the nonpublic data policy, and there were the Wikimedia-Community logo issue and this one about paid edits. All that require a lot of work from the community who have already a lot of work elsewhere (FDC reviewing, grants reviewing, OTRS, translation, reading the reports, etc.) without speaking of chapter-related work some people (FDC/grant proposal, searching money, doing programs, reporting, etc.) and also contribute to the Wikimedia projects themselves for some other people.

I’m absolutely not advocating against the openness, it’s really great, but could the WMF slow down the rhythm of the structural changes and/or try to better summarize the changes and/or try to better hear and respond to community requests and/or find ways to reduce the burden of the over-information within the movement? Today I have the feeling that the administrative tasks require so much time than programmative/contributive tasks suffer of a reduction of the available manpower.

~ Seb35 [^_^] 11:17, 22 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
français

Je commence à être fatigué de la modification (réflexion, traduction, faire des commentaires, avertir la communauté, re-réflexion, re-traduction, gérer les points bloquants, etc.) des politiques juridiques, entre autres. Depuis un an ont été changées : la politique de confidentialité, les conditions générales d’utilisation, la politique des marques, la politique de conservation des données, la politique des données non-publiques, et il y a eu le problème du logo de la Communauté Wikimedia et celui-ci sur les contributions payées. Tout cela demande beaucoup de travail de la part de la communauté qui a déjà beaucoup de travail ailleurs (relecture du FDC, relecture des subventions, OTRS, traduction, lire les rapports, etc.) sans parler du travail lié aux chapters pour quelques personnes (propositions de FDC/subventions, chercher de l’argent, faire les programmes, faire les rapports, etc.) ainsi que contribuer aux projets Wikimedia eux-mêmes pour quelques autres personnes.

Je ne suis absolument pas contre l’ouverture qui est vraiment formidable, mais j’aimerais que la WMF ralentisse le rythme des changements structurels et/ou essaye de mieux résumer les changements et/ou essaye de mieux écouter et répondre à la communauté et/ou trouve des moyens de réduire la charge de sur-information au sein du mouvement. Aujourd’hui, j’ai le sentiment que les tâches administratives demandent tant de temps que les tâches de contribution ou liées aux programmes souffrent d’une diminution de la main-d’œuvre disponible.

~ Seb35 [^_^] 11:17, 22 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
You and I both.  :) We needed to get our core governance documents in place, which we have done with the terms of use, privacy policy and trademark policy. Either these policies did not exist or were well outdated. After this consultation, I expect we will want to consult on the CC 4.0 license at some time. And then I don't expect much more from legal. Hope that gives some idea on where we see ourselves going. Cheers. Geoffbrigham (talk) 22:54, 27 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

A formatting bug in archives[edit]

In lower screen resolutions (here: lower than 1600×1200), large Table of Contents obliterates top section headers. Solution: remove clear:right;float:right. I can't do it because the template is edit-protected. Also must be checked in other Wikimedia projects for the same defect. (See Template talk:Archive header#Formatting bug.)
– 6birc (talk) 13:50, 22 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

WMF and its foray into paid POV advocacy editing[edit]

Those of you who are not on the Wikimedia-l mailing list have a right to know that the very organisation which is pushing for this amendment (the WMF) has been caught with its hand in the cookie jar. Editors may catch up at the archives ([Wikimedia-l] Timothy Sandole and (apparently) $53,690 of WMF funding), with some detailed analysis by myself here. Given that the impetus for this amendment was Sarah Stierch's ouster from the WMF for taking a $300 payment for editing an article on behalf of a paying client, it would be entirely inappropriate for the WMF board of trustees to endorse this amendment whilst the WMF's foray into paid editing, only being exposed, it still being investigated. Russavia (talk) 05:58, 23 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Point of information (taking no position at this time on the Sandole matter) - The impetus for this amendment was likely not the unfortunate Stierch kerfuffle, which would hardly warrant a revision of the terms-of-use, but rather the company "Wiki-PR" blowing off (politely) the legal cease-and-desist letter sent by the Wikimedia Foundation. See the article "PR Company Says It Was Demonized By The World's Biggest Internet Encyclopedia". To defeat a defense of no terms-of-use violation, the WMF response is to change the terms-of-use, to make it a terms-of-use violation. -- Seth Finkelstein (talk) 12:04, 23 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Without title[edit]

Wrongly posted in Talk:Terms of use/Paid contributions amendment/Archives, moved

I think having people have to say they are being paid, at least, is a good idea. If someone's being paid they have more of an incentive to keep changing a page back to the way they want it, possibly causing a more heated editing war. I don't even edit the articles on Wikipedia pages anymore, I've gotten so much trouble from weird people who want to have a page their way. And I knew I was right, too. I had books written by personal friends of a now dead famous person to back up my side. It didn't matter. I go to the talk page now if want to say something on Wikipedia. I think it would also be helpful if there was a function on Wikipedia that showed on the top of the page of an article a statement that people are editing the page are being paid to do it. Also, if there is an editing war going on and the site is being changed back and forth, I think that there should be a similar statement at the top of the page and a suggestion that people look at the talk page if they want to see all the conflicting views. I've run into people that trust the article pages on Wikipedia too much. They think that there must be a consensus for a page to be the way it is. In actual fact, people who are being paid or just are obsessed may just be spending way more time changing the page to their way, while more people think an opposite way, but just don't have time to edit the page all the time. 67.206.162.154 01:39, 15 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Undisclosed paid contributions are biased.[edit]

Wrongly posted in Talk:Terms of use/Paid contributions amendment/Archives, moved

A number of our entries is flagged with a statement to the effect, "This entry reads more like an advertisement . ." which is important to communicate. The proposed terms of use change will take some of the guesswork out of applying the "reader beware" label, and I support it wholeheartedly. The change still depends on contributors' honesty, so attention should be paid to verifying contributions which are paid for and/or biased, but not disclosed. Go for it! Let's work out the verification kinks as we go.— The preceding unsigned comment was added by 152.26.228.66 (talk) at 16:06, 17 March 2014 (UTC) how did you know i was into self-study? i am the editor-at-large if you know what i mean ..(: im sean 608 320 0386 66.112.113.224 06:55, 18 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

"The board will"[edit]

"As a next step, the Board will review the community comments" etc. etc. I don't understand, who decided this? The introduction in this page only said "The Wikimedia Foundation Legal Department plans to ask" etc. I didn't see any announcement about this item being on the board agenda. Just as a reminder, the board agenda is set by the board itself. --Nemo 17:45, 25 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Nemo, this is certainly on the Board's agenda - we attend closely to our counsel. We also aim to put community proposals on the agenda, when they arise, at the nearest opportunity. The agenda for the next Board meeting has not been fixed, but I expect this proposal will be discussed there if not before. Nevertheless, you are right that it would be clearer to write "the proposed amendment and options will be sent to the Board for review, along with a summary of the community's comments".
Two related comments for Stephen and team:
  • TOU changes are the mandate of the legal team. I understand that the Board's direct input is requested here because it is seen as a significant change, and the Board generally approves any wholesale rewrites or updates to the TOU. But while the Board will be happy to weigh in on this subject, I think the legal team could just as well decide to update the TOU on its own after such a public consult. You should feel comfortable making, evaluating, and changing or unmaking such changes as you see fit. Let's avoid creating the impression that any changes in this area, including later modifications or alterations, require month-long sitebanner saturation (roughly 10B? pageviews, almost all to logged-out readers) and Board approval. Both of those steps are normally overkill.
  • The Board will   have a limited amount of time. A clear proposal (it's hard for me to understand the implications of the Options section; perhaps some can be folded into a revised amendment?), a good closing summary, and an analysis of the three options and significant opposing views, would be most helpful.
Regards, and thanks for all of your work on this topic, –SJ talk  04:18, 31 March 2014 (UTC)[reply]
"Let's avoid creating the impression that any changes in this area, including later modifications or alterations, require month-long sitebanner saturation and Board approval. Both of those steps are normally overkill."
It's very concerning to see a board member take this stance considering Section 16 of the Terms of Use, which is linked right at the top of this page. This amendment is not necessary for pressing legal or administrative reasons. (Don't try to make the case that "well, all changes are legal or administrative." We need to get this vague loophole amended as well, hmm.) Nor was this in response to community consensus. All previous proposals in this vein have been shut down within the community itself. Therefore, yes, a minimum of 30 days for comment was required. And quietly proposing a channge without linking members to it would not be the same thing as opening the issue for comment to the community, therefore yes, the banner saturation was required.
Perhaps, indeed, asking the board is overkill, however I feel that if every board member has a similar lack of understanding of the only contract between Wikipedia and its authors, this could be a good opportunity for some education. Recursivelement (talk) 17:53, 1 April 2014 (UTC)[reply]
Hello Recursivelement, please reread my comment above. Section 16 clarifies that changes to the TOU require 30-60 days of public discussion and feedback. It does not require either a) a banner seen on ~10 billion pageviews over 30 days, or b) approval by the Board. (I added a few words to clarify what I mean by sitebanner saturation.) A banner notice for the logged-in community is certainly needed, as is announcement in all of the expected places: village pumps and other signposts. Showing the same banner to a cross-section of readers likewise makes sense, to get perspective from our reading community, though they may need additional context to understand what is at stake. But I hope most changes to the TOU can be handled with more focused iteration and less megaphone.
For reasons that you note, it is indeed appropriate for the legal team to consult with the Board before making any chances pursuant to this RFC. But we should be clear that the legal team is trusted and able to revise the TOU, based on both public consultation and consultation with the Board.
As for "legal and administrative reasons", that is a common bit of boilerplate. Do you have a preferred replacement? –SJ talk  17:45, 7 April 2014 (UTC)[reply]


I hadn't understood that the legal team can approve this itself - that's good to know. That said, I'm very glad that there was a month-long banner and will be (some sort of) Board approval. While various sorts of advertising, spamming, commercial editing have always been against the rules (as they came along), general regulation wasn't considered necessary - wasn't it obvious that commercial editing was against the Wikipedia way of doing things? With the rise of social media and the fairly recent recognition that Wikipedia is a pretty reliable source that everybody uses, there has been a wave of admen putting their garbage on Wikipedia. These admen seem to work together to control the discussions on Wikipedia (a la "regulatory capture"), thus we have had a gap between the apparent consensus on Wikipedia and the consensus (4-to-1 in favor of regulating paid editors) as shown here. Actually, I think that the real consensus is more than 90% in favor of regulating paid editors - paid editors have a big stake in commenting here and are likely over-represented. Thus I find the sentences above "Nor was this in response to community consensus. All previous proposals in this vein have been shut down within the community itself." to be offensive. There always has been a consensus that paid editors should be regulated, and there always will be such a consensus. Who wants an encyclopedia that is pitching products at them? With a concentrated band of editors who will always oppose such regulation, we do need to keep open the option of having a month-long banner and getting the real community involved in this type of thing. Smallbones (talk) 16:22, 2 April 2014 (UTC)[reply]
Offensive? Which part of the fact are you offended by? Can you show me a previous proposal in this vein which was not shut down by the community?
Perhaps you consider drive-by polling visitors to Wikipedia an accurate reflection of community consensus - I very much prefer the lengthy discussions by people heavily involved in the inner workings of Wikipedia, who understand what the stakes are. A significant number of people who voted here clearly didn't even understand what they were voting on. It's quite likely that an additional significant number of others didn't know what they were voting on, but didn't indicate it, or even more likely, had no idea of previous proposals and arguments or the extent of any problem, but simply dropped in, voted, and left (this applies to both sides). And I'd wager this is the reason for the apparent "change" in consensus. It's interesting to note that the voting is near snowballed, but the arguments themselves, and people willing to hash out ideas, are much more evenly balanced.
Regardless, my intention wasn't to make arguments for or against this amendment. I'd have done that earlier if I'd thought there was any point to the PR charade. I simply wanted to point out that this amendment didn't stem from legal or administrative requirements which cropped up, or from community outcry, and therefore didn't qualify for a speedy 3-day change. 12.234.227.194 17:51, 2 April 2014 (UTC) (logged out, apparently) Recursivelement (talk) 17:55, 2 April 2014 (UTC)[reply]
I'm offended by your implication that only the opinions of people who agree with you count. Paid editors, whose livelihood depends on it, can always get a bunch of people together to defeat a poorly publicized discussion, but when the RfC is publicized to the full community any proposal that effectively allows advertising inside Wikipedia articles will be roundly defeated. This type of advertising has never been allowed on Wikipedia, and never will be if the entire community is heard. 4 to 1 in the RfC with the largest participation in history might be difficult for paid editors to swallow, but they should get used to it. The choice for paid editors now will be whether they are going to try to undermine the implementation of the community's consensus (thus proving again why paid editors need to be regulated), or whether they want to help with reasonable regulation of paid editors. Smallbones (talk) 19:00, 3 April 2014 (UTC)[reply]
I'm also rather offended at the idea only the opinions of people who agree with you are well-formed or well-informed, and that others just drop in and leave. I myself have been editing on WP for less than a year and am indeed less aware of decisions or history at this level of the organization. But my relative inexperience here is not reflective of the substantial experience I bring from the outside. I didn't bother to register a vote; my vote is registered in the multiple comments I left in the discussion, and that vote says that paid editing is an idea that is basically inimical to the organization. Those who know how to manage the organization can now take that vote into consideration and decide what an appropriate response should be. My inexperience here need not bias their consideration. As far as community outcry is concerned, it is expressed in just such forums as this. There is no necessity that it be full-blown beforehand. Now those are fundamental outlooks regarding community participation and consensus that I with lesser experience understood very quickly, but which seems to escape the attention of those who don't like the fact that apparent consensus is not always actual consensus. The difference between the apparent and the real is exactly what this discussion has been about - how paid editing can distort one of the main working relationships the project depends on. So don't tell me I don't know what it is that I am voting on. Evensteven (talk) 20:12, 3 April 2014 (UTC)[reply]
I see none of you noted the tremendous number of people who dropped in to vote against paying to view Wikipedia articles? It's blatantly obvious a lot of voters didn't understand what this was about - if you weren't one of them, if you took the time to read, if you took part in the discussion rather than simply driving by, then good for you. I wasn't writing about you. You could take the time to parse my sentences and realize you don't fall into the group I'm discussing before being offended by them. Pointing out that voting "no, Wikipedia should be free forever" is completely irrelevant to this discussion is hardly a controversial fact. You can't demonstrate that the community discussions were secretly dominated by shills. But if you read up, you will discover multiple voters here clearly demonstrating they had no idea what was going on.
Go ahead, though, keep telling me the opposite is true. Why bother with facts, why bother with evidence, when you can have emotion?
At least I'm backing my claims up here, referencing solid facts which can be looked up by anyone curious. You're just spouting rhetoric which can't be proven right or wrong. Why should I believe that a bunch of people who voted "no, Wikipedia should be free forever" and everyone else with them, is a more accurate reflection of community consensus than discussions where people were actually addressing the issue at hand? I'd be insulted by your implication that every single previous discussion on this was bought out because they didn't agree with you, but I'm not quite so thin-skinned. Again, the people who actually discussed the matter were much more evenly balanced. Right in line with all previous proposals in this vein.
Finally, whether or not you believe this right here is consensus, the fact remains that people who remained quiet until after the proposal were not driving the proposal, therefore this was not in response to the community, therefore it did not qualify for the speedy 3-day instatement SJ appeared to be referencing. I don't care what your beliefs are otherwise. I'm amused that you're both insulted by cold, hard facts, though. You two are the only ones implying only those who agree with you count. Recursivelement (talk) 02:51, 4 April 2014 (UTC)[reply]
Correction: I was not referencing any 3-day process. (simply the high visibility of showing banners continuously to all logged-out readers.) –SJ talk 
Oh, please. I never said you didn't know what you were talking about either, nor that I couldn't accept the fact you disagree. "'no, Wikipedia should be free forever' is completely irrelevant to this discussion" is a part of your opinion; I don't see it that way. I'm not insulted by that. But I take issue with the idea that your opinion is a fact. You apparently see no value in the airing of opinion, which is part of what this discussion IS about. It's a basic principle of discussion here that the comments left behind are just as important as votes, and they will be viewed, weighed, and considered. Emotion? It also serves a purpose, and drives both human behavior and (often) human reasoning. It's human itself. I agree it can get irrational; I do not agree that it has made me so. And I do not agree that your arguments lack emotion either. That much is acceptable. I'm not entirely in agreement with many people on "my side" of this argument (I rarely am, in any argument). I think arguments (in reality) have many sides, many viewpoints, many angles, and a great many things worth considering. I learn from arguments, and often change my opinions because of listening to them. I object to your wholesale classification of this discussion into two narrowly-defined camps, and dismissing the value of anything that doesn't fall within those constraints. It has never been up to you to define what the discussion is about, much less to foretell what is going to have an impact on the outcome. Especially it is not up to you to dismiss other people because of whatever you may see as shortcomings. Maybe some have acted superficially - so what? Do you think others can't see that also? Are you offended that some of them may have voted? Why? Is the discussion narrowly defined as another undemocratic vote-fest? Is the tally only a matter of numbers? I prefer to stick with the theory that has always been on Wikipedia that comments count, and votes may be counted, but not necessarily equally. I think that it is insulting to be so dismissive; I take offense at that. I don't have to be taking it personally to take offense. But I'll take opportunity to use it to oppose narrow and restrictive thinking. You may have your hard, cold facts. There are warm, soft ones that count too. One thing is abundantly clear from this discussion: the warm issues (there are many of them) are much bigger and more significant than the literal proposal, and the "vote". Evensteven (talk) 03:18, 5 April 2014 (UTC)[reply]
Thanks Sj for the answer. I'm looking forwad to hearing the legal department's reply and an official announcement on the board agenda.
It also makes sense to me that the board may decide to delegate the matter to the legal department if they don't feel strongly about any of the options or otherwise consider their evaluation not to be their priority. However, considering that this amendment would directly supplant a number of local wiki policies and guidelines and therefore represent a substantial power structure (constitutional) shift in Wikimedia projects, with a whole massive area of regulation transferred from the community to the Wikimedia Foundation (and from editors self-regulation to legal obligations), I think such a delegation would need to be explicitly decided with a board resolution. While individual changes to the terms of use may need varying degrees of approval, a change of the role itself of the terms of use certainly requires the highest possible rank of approval. --Nemo 15:17, 6 April 2014 (UTC)[reply]
Nemo - this is well said. The Board should resolve the scope of change that is appropriate to make in this area, and any significant change in the role of the TOU. We need to be better about delegation: for instance, we might resolve to delegate making, evaluating and revising such amendments to the legal team. Followed by non-resolution guidance regarding one of the proposed options, or a variation, that seems reasonable to the Board. Without clear delegation, people can variously post concerns in multiple places, write to the LCA, ping the ED, ping Jimmy, or petition the Board directly: leading to confusion, exhaustion, and forum shopping. –SJ talk  18:41, 7 April 2014 (UTC)[reply]

@Sj:, throughout this process the WMF staff have mentioned that WMF board approval will be sought, so it would be a very big shock if one or more of these proposed amendments were to be enacted without a board resolution. (search this talk page for 'board' and you will see many instances) In any case, I agree with Nemo that it would be wise for significant amendments like those proposed to be made only by resolution of the WMF Board. There are some legal underpinnings to these amendment propositions, being the laws about astroturfing/unfair competition/fraud/etc, but none of the amendment options are merely legal - they all go beyond what is required by law, for good or ill, and impose policy on the projects, and will force some community members to retire due to the serious legal threats posed elsewhere in the Terms of Use (but to be fair, it may change the culture significantly and result in hordes of new contributors...).
If the board cant approve any of the proposed amendments, a carefully and conservatively written amendment to highlight legal disclosure requirements could be a first step forward, and could be done under the "changes for legal .. reasons" provision of Section 16. Essentially change 'you must disclose' to 'you may be required by law to disclose' and indicate that paid contributors should consult a lawyer to determine the applicable legal requirements of both their jurisdiction and those of the U.S. So simple ... and probably just as effective. hehe John Vandenberg (talk) 04:03, 7 April 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Hello John, I'd like to discuss further how you see significant policy amendments being made. Perhaps at Talk:Terms of Use? I expect most amendments would not be nearly this controversial.
To this specific amendment - I expect there will be a Board vote related to this, and Board guidance on one of the resolutions or a variant. I agree with you that a clear, stepwise approach would start with a minimal amendment that highlights legal disclosure requirements. Then we would now be discussing whether to change or amplify that: the public discussion would have been shorter and less confusing.
In my view, the reason we haven't adopted that sort of approach is a lack of practice in revising policies, because any time it happens it is a treated as a huge deal; so people try to pack all possible changes into one. Which is my motivation for reducing rather than increasing red tape. –SJ talk  18:41, 7 April 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Sj, when you say "I think the legal team could just as well decide to update the TOU on its own after such a public consult.", doesn't that in practice essentially permit the General Counsel to update the TOU on his/her own? (I presume the rest of the legal team reports to the GC, and in any case, can't formally override the GC even if hypothetically they wanted to do so). That's a huge amount of power for any one person to have. While the current GC seems very collaborative and respectful of objections, such power in the hands of a by-any-means-necessary lawyer could be extremely dangerous. Could the terms-of-use be updated by the GC to have an indemnification clause? A non-disparagement clause? If you say no, why are those categorically different from some sort of mandatory disclosure, where I believe the discussion above has identified several problems? If you say yes, well, that's a problem itself. This amendment strikes me as having turned into a case study of a lesson in why the legal team should not make nontrivial changes on its own authority (no offense meant to legal team members here, just being descriptive). There's serious tension between what they might want for legal battles, and the externalities which might be imposed on everyone else. And that conflict is why TOU changes should be examined by as many stakeholders as possible. -- Seth Finkelstein (talk) 10:44, 7 April 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Hi Seth, this is how I understand the current process: The GC and team are currently able to update the TOU, after a translated explanation and well-publicized community consultation of 30-60 days. That's a strong commitment to examination by many stakeholders. The Board is informed of such policy changes, and generally asked for informal approval, but is not required to pass a resolution approving policy updates. For major policy overhauls, a Board vote may still be requested.
Bear in mind that the GC does not have independent authority: the ED, and the Board in turn, have the power to stop or alter any such actions. We would not allow the sorts of changes you hypothesize, under either process. The question is what mandatory procedural hoops are jumped through before changes are implemented. –SJ talk  18:41, 7 April 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Status?[edit]

How are things proceeding? Anyone? Per WMF_Board_meetings it looks like there are generally around 7 board meetings a month - and that page is woefully out of date, or meetings are much less frequent now. ??? [4] still stands.--Elvey (talk) 02:19, 6 May 2014 (UTC)[reply]

It seems the board met April 24 and 25. [5]--Elvey (talk) 02:37, 6 May 2014 (UTC)[reply]
Why is there no decision? It does not take this long even considering the diverse range of opinions which were voiced. Come on!--Xania (talk) 19:23, 21 May 2014 (UTC)[reply]
Hello Elvey and Xania, the Board discussed this at the April 25 Board meeting, and I expect that they will publish the results of the meeting in the next few weeks. Thanks, Stephen LaPorte (WMF) (talk) 20:14, 21 May 2014 (UTC)[reply]
Have they done this? If so, where? 180.200.187.189 02:46, 5 June 2014 (UTC).[reply]
Hello all, you can find the update in the Terms of Use. More information is available in this blog post. Thanks! Stephen LaPorte (WMF) (talk) 16:53, 16 June 2014 (UTC)[reply]

Difference between employer and client[edit]

Hi.

  • What is the difference between employer and client? If a freelancer is hired by a company A, for creating an article, the client is the person who initially hired the company A? If I am right, then the freelancer can not know the client, if exist or not. So, what should the freelance put about the client in the disclosure? Unknown client? And what if the client doesnt exist?. Thanks in advance--Rndmdf (talk) 23:00, 9 September 2014 (UTC)[reply]
  • Secondly, if a company/person Z hire a freelance, then the company/person Z is the client, and the employer doesnt exist. Can anybody answer me, please? Thanks--Rndmdf (talk) 10:09, 10 September 2014 (UTC)[reply]
Hello Rndmdf, an editor should fully disclose his or her financial connection to the topic that he or she is editing. If one cannot provide the necessary disclosure, then he or she may need to refrain from editing. We also posted an explanation in the FAQ: What does the phrase “employer, client, and affiliation” mean?. I hope that is helpful. For more detail about what sort of disclosure is appropriate, I would encourage you to consult local conflict of interest policies (such as WP:COI on English Wikipedia). Thanks, Stephen LaPorte (WMF) (talk) 16:50, 10 September 2014 (UTC)[reply]
